abstract: A Senate report highlights several trends related to care for people with Alzheimer’s disease in five countries.
snippet: A Senate report highlights several trends related to care for people with Alzheimer’s disease in five countries.
lead_paragraph: This month, the United States Senate Special Committee on Aging released a report examining how five nations — the United States, Australia, France, Japan and Britain — are responding to growing numbers of older adults with Alzheimer’s disease and dementia.

headline.main: United States Lags in Alzheimer’s Support

abstract: One wife caring for another — another example of how the new old age is spawning unusual and creative alliances.
snippet: One wife caring for another — another example of how the new old age is spawning unusual and creative alliances.
lead_paragraph: Weather permitting, Kappy Lundy and Barbara Thompson are heading out to Vancouver, Wash., on Saturday night to have a holiday dinner with the parents of their daughter’s husband.
headline.main: The Ex-Wives Club

abstract: Degenerative relationships are not uncommon among the elderly in even the happiest marriages. Both mental and physical changes feed the discord, marriage therapists and geriatricians say.
snippet: Degenerative relationships are not uncommon among the elderly in even the happiest marriages. Both mental and physical changes feed the discord, marriage therapists and geriatricians say.
lead_paragraph: George and Gracie (let’s call them that because using their real names would make them even unhappier than they already appear to be) are in their 80s and have been married for more than 65 years. Until recently they seemed to ride the waves that are inevitable in any marriage that spans nearly seven decades; through good and bad, they were partners and best friends.
headline.main: In the Middle: Why Elderly Couples Fight

abstract: Sidney Gilman, a top Alzheimer’s researcher, oversaw the trials for a drug developed by Wyeth and Elan that had the potential to help Alzheimer’s patients. Just days before publicly presenting disappointing results from the drug’s trial in 2008, Dr. Gilman provided the data to Mathew Martoma, a trader affiliated with SAC Capital, prosecutors say, allowing Mr. Martoma to sell the stock and avoid big losses.
snippet: Sidney Gilman, a top Alzheimer’s researcher, oversaw the trials for a drug developed by Wyeth and Elan that had the potential to help Alzheimer’s patients. Just days before publicly presenting disappointing results from the drug’s trial in 2008, D...
lead_paragraph: Sidney Gilman, a top Alzheimer’s researcher, oversaw the trials for a drug developed by Wyeth and Elan that had the potential to help Alzheimer’s patients. Just days before publicly presenting disappointing results from the drug’s trial in 2008, Dr. Gilman provided the data to Mathew Martoma, a trader affiliated with SAC Capital, prosecutors say, allowing Mr. Martoma to sell the stock and avoid big losses.
headline.main: A Stock’s Rise and Fall

abstract: Since Mom took off in my car almost a year ago, after we had had a fight, I had hidden the keys. Except for this week; after the death of my son, I had forgotten.
snippet: Since Mom took off in my car almost a year ago, after we had had a fight, I had hidden the keys. Except for this week; after the death of my son, I had forgotten.
lead_paragraph: My friend Yvonne was already at the front door when I woke, so at first I didn’t realize that my mother was missing.
headline.main: A Son Lost, a Mother Found

abstract: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy of Duke University addresses reader questions about the cause and diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease and other memory problems.
snippet: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy of Duke University addresses reader questions about the cause and diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease and other memory problems.
lead_paragraph: Readers recently submitted more than 100 questions about Alzheimer’s and memory loss to this week’s expert, Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy, a psychiatry professor at Duke University Medical Center and an author of “The Alzheimer’s Action Plan.” Dr. Doraiswamy has also been an adviser to government agencies, advocacy groups and businesses.

abstract: In recent years, some research has suggested that a high-fat diet may be bad for the brain, at least in lab animals. Can exercise protect against such damage?
snippet: In recent years, some research has suggested that a high-fat diet may be bad for the brain, at least in lab animals. Can exercise protect against such damage?
lead_paragraph: In recent years, some research has suggested that a high-fat diet may be bad for the brain, at least in lab animals. Can exercise protect against such damage? That question may have particular relevance now, with the butter-and cream-laden holidays fast approaching. And it has prompted several new and important studies.

abstract: Even many health care professionals remain unfamiliar with Lewy body dementia, though it affects about 1.3 million people in this country.
snippet: Even many health care professionals remain unfamiliar with Lewy body dementia, though it affects about 1.3 million people in this country.
lead_paragraph: Lori Roberts’s father, who used to deliver the mail in Mitchell, S.D., has undergone startling personality changes. “He used to be very easygoing,” Ms. Roberts said. “Now he’s gotten kind of physical with my mom and my brother, pushing and shoving.” The other day, when her exhausted mother visited him in the nursing home he had recently entered — by sad coincidence, it was their 53rd wedding anniversary – he loudly insisted that she take him to Mexico, immediately.

headline.main: A Form of Dementia That Is Often Misdiagnosed

abstract: Children’s books tackle a hard and sensitive topic.
snippet: Children’s books tackle a hard and sensitive topic.
lead_paragraph: I stopped at a children’s bookshop in Manhattan last week and asked to see books on Alzheimer’s disease. The store stocked at least half a dozen, with titles like “What’s Wrong with Grandma?” and “What’s Happening to Grandpa?”
headline.main: Books to Teach Children About Alzheimer’s

abstract: About 20 percent of hospital patients over 65 experience delirium-related complications, but with prompt recognition and proper management episodes can be shortened, suffering alleviated and costs reduced.
snippet: About 20 percent of hospital patients over 65 experience delirium-related complications, but with prompt recognition and proper management episodes can be shortened, suffering alleviated and costs reduced.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to be elderly, or even very old, to develop delirium, a kind of brain attack often accompanied by hallucinations, agitation and disorientation that can exacerbate illness, increase medical costs and even hasten death.

abstract: Alex Witchel describes how her vibrant mother’s personality vanished despite her robust body.
snippet: Alex Witchel describes how her vibrant mother’s personality vanished despite her robust body.
lead_paragraph: In this haunting, unflinching and at times unexpectedly hilarious memoir, Alex Witchel offers up a fiercely honest account of how her adored mother slowly began “disappearing in plain sight.” “All Gone” is a potluck dish containing a variety of ingredients: childhood stories, complete with a cast of vibrantly portrayed relatives; practical knowledge gleaned from Witchel’s desperate battle against the relentless advance of her parent’s small-stroke-induced dementia; and, yes, real recipes passed down by her mother and grandmother. (I’ve tried a few, and they’re very good. I particularly recommend the chicken with prunes.)

abstract: My father’s dementia told me things about him that he never could or never would tell me himself.
snippet: My father’s dementia told me things about him that he never could or never would tell me himself.
lead_paragraph: I was the copy editor assigned to work on Alex Witchel’s memoir about her mother’s dementia. I was fortunate because her writing is compelling and didn’t need any help from me, and also because it forced me to focus on the quality of my father’s dementia, maybe for the first time.
headline.main: What My Father’s Dementia Told Me

abstract: Recent research suggests that loneliness is a risk factor for functional decline and early death in later life.
snippet: Recent research suggests that loneliness is a risk factor for functional decline and early death in later life.
lead_paragraph: YOU die alone, philosophers say. But you could die sooner if you live your life in loneliness. Close connections to friends and family may ward off poor health and premature death, recent research suggests.

abstract: A new randomized placebo-controlled study by French researchers indicates that ginkgo biloba extract does not work as a preventive for Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: A new randomized placebo-controlled study by French researchers indicates that ginkgo biloba extract does not work as a preventive for Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Ginkgo biloba extract is widely marketed as a preventive for Alzheimer’s disease, but a new randomized placebo-controlled study indicates it does not work.

abstract: Scientists find a new indicator of cognitive decline.
snippet: Scientists find a new indicator of cognitive decline.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports on Tuesday morning on five new studies suggesting that changes in the way an older person walks may be among the earliest indicators of cognitive decline, including Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: A New Test for Dementia: Walking

abstract: Ray Easterling, a retired Atlanta Falcons safety who committed suicide in April, had the degenerative disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, according to an autopsy report.
snippet: Ray Easterling, a retired Atlanta Falcons safety who committed suicide in April, had the degenerative disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, according to an autopsy report.
lead_paragraph: An autopsy report released this week, just before N.F.L. training camps opened, concluded that the former Atlanta Falcons safety Ray Easterling, who committed suicide in April, had a degenerative brain disease widely connected to athletes who have absorbed frequent blows to the head.

abstract: At a California prison, prisoners doing time for murder are caring for inmates with Alzheimer’s disease and other dementia.
snippet: At a California prison, prisoners doing time for murder are caring for inmates with Alzheimer’s disease and other dementia.
lead_paragraph: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif. — Secel Montgomery Sr. stabbed a woman in the stomach, chest and throat so fiercely that he lost count of the wounds he inflicted. In the nearly 25 years he has been serving a life sentence, he has gotten into fights, threatened a prison official and been caught with marijuana.

abstract: A residential complex in the Netherlands that tries to help dementia patients continue to lead a normal life has received attention as a model.
snippet: A residential complex in the Netherlands that tries to help dementia patients continue to lead a normal life has received attention as a model.
lead_paragraph: WEESP, the Netherlands — The sparkling-new 23-unit Hogewey complex here is virtually indistinguishable from other residential developments in the area. The apartments open onto a courtyard with benches, ponds and fountains, with beds of flowers in season (this is the Netherlands, after all). One kidney-shaped pond planted with reeds and other vegetation occasionally attracts wild ducks.

abstract: A new film attempts to see life through the eyes of someone with Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: A new film attempts to see life through the eyes of someone with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Scott Kirschenbaum’s new film, “You’re Looking at Me Like I Live Here and I Don’t,” was supposed to be scripted and cast — a coherent story with a beginning, a middle and an end. Then he found his unlikely star: Lee Gorewitz, 78, who lives in dementia unit at Reutlinger Community for Jewish Living in Danville, Calif.
headline.main: Dementia, From the Inside

abstract: The prison system is struggling to cope with a rising tide of older, sicker inmates. States must pursue other avenues.
snippet: The prison system is struggling to cope with a rising tide of older, sicker inmates. States must pursue other avenues.
lead_paragraph: The get-tough-on-crime and mandatory sentencing policies that swept America beginning in the 1970s did more than drive up the inmate population and prison costs. They also ensured that inmates who once might have been seen as rehabilitated and given parole would grow old and even die behind bars. As a result, prisons are struggling to furnish costly, specialized care to ever more inmates who suffer from age-related infirmities, especially dementia.
headline.main: Dementia Behind Bars
headline.print_headline: Dementia Behind Bars

abstract: Scientists think that abnormal protein deposits inside brain cells cause frontotemporal degeneration.
snippet: Scientists think that abnormal protein deposits inside brain cells cause frontotemporal degeneration.
lead_paragraph: “If there’s something to be done, I want to be in on the ground floor,” said Elizabeth, 67, a woman participating in studies of frontotemporal degeneration at the University of California, San Francisco.
headline.main: Studies Tie Abnormal Protein Buildup to Dementia
headline.print_headline: Studies Tie Abnormal Protein Buildup to Dementia

abstract: In a lecture to students in Cartagena, Colombia, the younger brother of the author told the audience that Gabriel García Márquez “is doing well physically, but he has been suffering from dementia for a long time.”
snippet: In a lecture to students in Cartagena, Colombia, the younger brother of the author told the audience that Gabriel García Márquez “is doing well physically, but he has been suffering from dementia for a long time.”
lead_paragraph: 9:43 a.m. | Updated
headline.main: Brother Says García Márquez Has Dementia

abstract: When elderly New Yorkers with dementia wander away from their homes, the police issue a bulletin called a silver alert.
snippet: When elderly New Yorkers with dementia wander away from their homes, the police issue a bulletin called a silver alert.
lead_paragraph: Irwin Goffman, an 83-year-old retired sociology professor, sat in the waiting room of an Upper West Side doctor’s office on Wednesday afternoon while his wife went in for a checkup. The couple had taken a train from Massachusetts; they moved there from Greenwich Village a year and a half ago, partly for the change of scenery after he left New York University. And partly because of what was happening to Mr. Goffman.

lead_paragraph: Ralph Wenzel, a former National Football League lineman whose early-onset dementia helped draw attention to recent debates about the safety of football, died on June 18 in Annapolis, Md. He was 69.

abstract: After choosing to restrict hitting in practices, the country’s largest youth football program is still faced with the issue of how much further it may want — or need — to go.
snippet: After choosing to restrict hitting in practices, the country’s largest youth football program is still faced with the issue of how much further it may want — or need — to go.
lead_paragraph: The unremarkable football career of Dr. Julian Bailes, who is now the chairman of the Pop Warner medical advisory board, ended quietly during his college days in the 1970s. He never sustained a concussion that he knew of, but he can recall a friend in high school who did. Confused and concussed, his friend started describing a car he had just bought; there was no new car, and Bailes found it hilarious. “We didn’t know any better,” he said.

lead_paragraph: Some studies have linked dietary fat to the development of dementia later in life. A new study suggests that the risk may depend on the type of fat consumed.

abstract: A documentary director and a social worker hatch a new idea: personalized music for every nursing home resident.
snippet: A documentary director and a social worker hatch a new idea: personalized music for every nursing home resident.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you’re among the millions who’ve watched and forwarded this video of an unresponsive 94-year-old with dementia, slumped in his wheelchair at a nursing home in Brooklyn. But when a staff member puts earphones in place and clicks on an iPod loaded with favorite hymns, he awakens, moving to the music, humming along.
headline.main: Revived by Music

abstract: Like many others, Ruth French finds herself grappling with her spouse’s frontotemporal dementia, a group of brain diseases that eat away at personality and language.
snippet: Like many others, Ruth French finds herself grappling with her spouse’s frontotemporal dementia, a group of brain diseases that eat away at personality and language.
lead_paragraph: He threw away tax documents, got a ticket for trying to pass an ambulance and bought stock in companies that were obviously in trouble. Once a good cook, he burned every pot in the house. He became withdrawn and silent, and no longer spoke to his wife over dinner. That same failure to communicate got him fired from his job at a consulting firm.

abstract: In a case brought by former players and their wives against the N.F.L. and the helmet maker Riddell, the suicide of former Falcons player Ray Easterling is cited in federal court on Wednesday.
snippet: In a case brought by former players and their wives against the N.F.L. and the helmet maker Riddell, the suicide of former Falcons player Ray Easterling is cited in federal court on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The suicide last week of Ray Easterling, a player with the Atlanta Falcons in the 1970s who was being treated for dementia, took center stage in court on Wednesday.
headline.main: In Court, Easterling Suicide Is the Focus

abstract: A new book and photo exhibition this month in New York shows another side of Alzheimer’s, one in which people with the disease can still be engaged, lead active lives and experience love and joy.
snippet: A new book and photo exhibition this month in New York shows another side of Alzheimer’s, one in which people with the disease can still be engaged, lead active lives and experience love and joy.
lead_paragraph: The prevailing view of people with Alzheimer’s is often a depressing one: the patient slumped in a chair or parked in front of a television set. But a new book and photo exhibition this month in New York show another side of the disease, one in which people with dementia can still be engaged, lead active lives and experience love and joy.

headline.main: The Faces of Alzheimer’s

abstract: Imagining another’s wishes.
snippet: Imagining another’s wishes.
lead_paragraph: My sister, who was born with Down syndrome, has end-stage dementia with advanced Parkinson’s disease. She can no longer recognize anyone, and her quality of life is limited to eating and sleeping. Now her doctors are asking me to let them insert a feeding tube, which would keep her from choking but prevent her from ever actually eating again. I love her. How can I remove one of her last pleasures? Should I make the decision for her that I would want for myself in similar circumstances? NAME WITHHELD,  New York

abstract: The state troopers asked us both to sit down, and I knew it would be terrible. Mom was not ready for this.
snippet: The state troopers asked us both to sit down, and I knew it would be terrible. Mom was not ready for this.
lead_paragraph: Heavy boots woke me. They struck the floor upstairs like mallets on a wooden gong. They paced the room above, paused, then paced back again.
headline.main: ‘Do You Know Who Died?’

abstract: A partial resolution in a widely publicized case that raised questions about abuse of the elderly.
snippet: A partial resolution in a widely publicized case that raised questions about abuse of the elderly.
lead_paragraph: The Times reported on Wednesday that a settlement had been reached in the court battle over the estate of Brooke Astor, the queen of New York society who died in 2007 at age 105 after a long struggle with dementia. Her son, Anthony Marshall, and Francis X. Morrissey Jr., a lawyer who did estate planning for Mrs. Astor, were convicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of defrauding and stealing from her. Both have appealed.
headline.main: A Settlement in the Astor Case

abstract: There is hopeful news in the battle against this incurable disease: scientists and the Obama administration are making progress on this intractable form of dementia.
snippet: There is hopeful news in the battle against this incurable disease: scientists and the Obama administration are making progress on this intractable form of dementia.
lead_paragraph: There is hopeful news in the battle against Alzheimer’s disease, a type of dementia that gradually robs millions of older Americans of their memories and mental capacities and ultimately kills them. Scientists are beginning to close in on possible diagnostic tests and treatments for this incurable disease. And the Obama administration, carrying out a law enacted in 2010, has just issued a “draft framework” for an aggressive campaign to prevent and treat Alzheimer’s disease effectively by 2025.
headline.main: The Campaign to Defeat Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: The Campaign to Defeat Alzheimer’s

abstract: A poem by Rachel Hadas about her husband’s dementia.
snippet: A poem by Rachel Hadas about her husband’s dementia.
lead_paragraph: When the person talking to you about spousal caregiving is an award-winning poet and essayist like Rachel Hadas, you should let her speak for herself. Herewith, a small excerpt from her book “Strange Relation: A Memoir of Dementia, Caregiving, and Poetry,” published last year.
headline.main: In Caregiving, a New Silence

abstract: Researchers update “The 36-Hour Day.”
snippet: Researchers update “The 36-Hour Day.”
lead_paragraph: More than 30 years ago, when the psychiatrist Dr. Peter Rabins and the psychologist Nancy Mace began working with dementia patients and their families at Johns Hopkins Hospital, they had to write and mimeograph (younger readers: look it up) small pamphlets to explain to them what was going on and what was to come.
headline.main: The Caregivers’ Bookshelf: An Alzheimer’s Classic

abstract: A study of older adults finds that those with higher omega-3 fatty acid levels had larger brain volume and performed better in tests of mental acuity.
snippet: A study of older adults finds that those with higher omega-3 fatty acid levels had larger brain volume and performed better in tests of mental acuity.
lead_paragraph: Low blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids are associated with smaller brain volume and poorer performance on tests of mental acuity, even in people without apparent dementia, according to a new study.

abstract: “The Iron Lady” does not sidestep Margaret Thatcher’s dementia.
snippet: “The Iron Lady” does not sidestep Margaret Thatcher’s dementia.
lead_paragraph: Even if I hadn’t been a worshipful fan of Meryl Streep since 1978, even if she hadn’t won yet another Oscar nomination for playing Margaret Thatcher, I would’ve gone to see “The Iron Lady.” The ways in which popular culture portrays aging these days seem worth paying attention to.
headline.main: The Lioness in Winter

abstract: Michael French has frontotemporal dementia, for which there is no treatment. As his condition deteriorated, his wife, Ruth, had to move him to a nursing home, where she spends most days.

abstract: This “hidden” disability, currently untreated in about 85 percent of those affected, may be the nation’s most damaging sensory handicap.
snippet: This “hidden” disability, currently untreated in about 85 percent of those affected, may be the nation’s most damaging sensory handicap.
lead_paragraph: Hearing loss, a disability currently untreated in about 85 percent of those affected, may be the nation’s most damaging and costly sensory handicap. It is a hidden disability, often not obvious to others or even to those who have it.

snippet: Examining the worldwide struggle to find answers about Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Examining the worldwide struggle to find answers about Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: Vanishing Minds Series

abstract: I left my elderly mother at a table, eating lunch. When I returned, she was nowhere to be found.
snippet: I left my elderly mother at a table, eating lunch. When I returned, she was nowhere to be found.
lead_paragraph: I gawk at the chair where I’d left Mom waiting for me. She’s gone. I scan the lounge, a midsize room of muted grays and whites. There’s a disheveled young man stretched out on the blue sofa, a few students eating lunch at the tables, a row of anonymous computer stations by the wall. Panic flutters in my throat.
headline.main: She’s Gone Missing

abstract: Some museums offer tours for elderly patrons with dementia and their caregivers.
snippet: Some museums offer tours for elderly patrons with dementia and their caregivers.
lead_paragraph: At the Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan, David Rosenberg, a guide, stood before a stone piece depicting a six-armed figure. “Now, what would be a good reason to have six arms?” Mr. Rosenberg asked his audience, a half dozen or so elderly adults with dementia and their caregivers.
headline.main: Reconnecting Through Art
byline.original: By Alyson Martin and Nushin Rashidian

abstract: The actress performs a scene from Bruce Graham’s play about a family dealing with dementia.
snippet: The actress performs a scene from Bruce Graham’s play about a family dealing with dementia.
lead_paragraph: The actress Michael Learned performs a scene from “The Outgoing Tide.” Bruce Graham’s play, at 59E59 Theaters through Sunday, is a drama about a blue-collar family facing issues of death and morality. In this excerpt, Peg (Ms. Learned) speaks to her son about his father, who is suffering from dementia.
headline.main: In Performance: Michael Learned of ‘The Outgoing Tide’

abstract: Todd Heisler spent four days photographing the members of a unique program at the California Men’s Colony that pairs inmates with dementia with caretakers — other inmates.
snippet: Todd Heisler spent four days photographing the members of a unique program at the California Men’s Colony that pairs inmates with dementia with caretakers — other inmates.
lead_paragraph: There are constant reminders of the outside world at the California Men’s Colony. The prison, nestled in the seaside mountains outside of San Luis Obispo, is routinely enveloped by a thick fog that rolls in from the ocean at dawn. Seagulls and other birds fly overhead, stop occasionally to perch on the razor wire encircling the yard, and fly away at a whim. The birds are a reminder of the world outside, which many people in this prison will never again experience.
headline.main: Behind Bars and Beginning to Forget

snippet: A researcher at the University of Toronto answers questions about detecting and dealing with mild cognitive impairment.
lead_paragraph: About 10 to 15 percent of adults age 65 and older are believed to have mild cognitive impairment — a condition commonly characterized by memory problems, well beyond those associated with normal aging.
headline.main: Coping With Mild Cognitive Impairment

abstract: Five studies presented this month provide striking evidence that when a person’s walk gets slower or becomes more variable or less controlled, his cognitive function is also suffering.
snippet: Five studies presented this month provide striking evidence that when a person’s walk gets slower or becomes more variable or less controlled, his cognitive function is also suffering.
lead_paragraph: The way people walk appears to speak volumes about the way they think, so much so that changes in an older person’s gait appear to be an early indicator of cognitive impairment, including Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: Footprints to Cognitive Decline and Alzheimer’s Are Seen in Gait
headline.print_headline: Footprints to Cognitive Decline and Alzheimer’s Are Seen in Gait

abstract: Gordie Howe has “memory challenges,” his son says, but the man known as Mr. Hockey has a full schedule, including events to raise funds for research into Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Gordie Howe has “memory challenges,” his son says, but the man known as Mr. Hockey has a full schedule, including events to raise funds for research into Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: While Thursday morning’s reports of Gordie Howe’s dementia may have been exaggerated to a certain degree, according to his sons Marty and Murray, the overall point remains that, memory deficits or no, Mr. Hockey has a remarkably busy schedule for a man his age.

snippet: A study of a large family with Alzheimer’s found that its precursors begin even earlier than previously thought, and that the brain may deteriorate in more ways than has been documented before.
lead_paragraph: Scientists studying Alzheimer’s disease are increasingly finding clues that the brain begins to deteriorate years before a person shows symptoms of dementia.

abstract: Mild cognitive impairment, or M.C.I., involves a decline in mental acuity noticeable by oneself and others but not severe enough to be diagnosed as dementia.
snippet: Mild cognitive impairment, or M.C.I., involves a decline in mental acuity noticeable by oneself and others but not severe enough to be diagnosed as dementia.
lead_paragraph: A nicotine patch worn for six months can improve attention, memory and mental processing in people with mild cognitive impairment, a clinical trial has found.
headline.main: Nicotine Patch Helps Against Cognitive Impairment in Study
headline.print_headline: Aging: Nicotine Patch Helps Against Cognitive Impairment in Study

abstract: A daily walk or jog could alter the risk of developing Alzheimer’s or change the course of the disease if it begins in some people, a new study suggests.
snippet: A daily walk or jog could alter the risk of developing Alzheimer’s or change the course of the disease if it begins in some people, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Alzheimer’s disease, with its inexorable loss of memory and self, understandably alarms most of us. This is especially so since, at the moment, there are no cures for the condition and few promising drug treatments. But a cautiously encouraging new study from The Archives of Neurology suggests that for some people, a daily walk or jog could alter the risk of developing Alzheimer’s or change the course of the disease if it begins.
headline.main: How Exercise May Keep Alzheimer’s at Bay
headline.print_headline: Exercise May Throw Up an Alzheimeru2019s Roadblock

abstract: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy of Duke University addresses reader questions about Alzheimer’s disease and other memory problems.
snippet: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy of Duke University addresses reader questions about Alzheimer’s disease and other memory problems.
lead_paragraph: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy, a psychiatry professor at Duke University Medical Center and an author of “The Alzheimer’s Action Plan,” has been answering readers’ questions about Alzheimer’s disease and memory problems. Part 1 of responses can be found here, and Part 2, is here. In our third and final part, he responds to questions dealing with treatment, patient care and new clinical trials.

abstract: Images of athletes’ brains illustrate the deterioration that can be caused by repeated mild head traumas.
snippet: Images of athletes’ brains illustrate the deterioration that can be caused by repeated mild head traumas.
lead_paragraph: Images of athletes’ brains illustrate the deterioration that can be caused by repeated mild head traumas.
headline.main: Images of Brain Injuries in Athletes

abstract: For those in midlife and beyond, a college degree appears to slow the brain’s aging process by up to a decade, adding a new twist to the cost-benefit analysis of higher education.
snippet: For those in midlife and beyond, a college degree appears to slow the brain’s aging process by up to a decade, adding a new twist to the cost-benefit analysis of higher education.
lead_paragraph: Research shows that education is an essential element to keeping the brain fit as it ages, an issue explored by the New York Times reporter Patricia Cohen in the latest issue of Education Life.
headline.main: Boosting Mental Fitness in Middle Age

abstract: With so many patients having to choose between nursing homes and palliative care, the Affordable Care Act calls for a three-year experiment of “concurrent care,” but no target date to begin has been set.
snippet: With so many patients having to choose between nursing homes and palliative care, the Affordable Care Act calls for a three-year experiment of “concurrent care,” but no target date to begin has been set.
lead_paragraph: I wrote last week about the poor choices facing patients, most very old and within six months of death, who need nursing home care after a hospitalization.

abstract: A disproportionate number of men who played at least five seasons in the N.F.L. from 1959 to 1988 developed Alzheimer’s disease or Lou Gehrig’s disease, according to a study released Wednesday.
snippet: A disproportionate number of men who played at least five seasons in the N.F.L. from 1959 to 1988 developed Alzheimer’s disease or Lou Gehrig’s disease, according to a study released Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A disproportionate number of men who played at least five seasons in the N.F.L. from 1959 to 1988 developed Alzheimer’s disease or Lou Gehrig’s disease, according to a study released Wednesday.
headline.main: Study Finds Increased Risks for N.F.L. Players
headline.print_headline: Study Finds Risk of Brain Disease for N.F.L. Players

abstract: Getting travel refunds if the price drops, how medical debts can stain your credit history, coupon-clipping your way to economic rebirth and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
snippet: Getting travel refunds if the price drops, how medical debts can stain your credit history, coupon-clipping your way to economic rebirth and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.
headline.main: Monday Reading: Getting Travel Refunds if the Price Drops

abstract: “Ruth & Erica,” a YouTube drama, is the latest in a series of movies, TV shows and books that focus on aging.
snippet: “Ruth & Erica,” a YouTube drama, is the latest in a series of movies, TV shows and books that focus on aging.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t want to take care of them,” Erica confesses in Episode 12 to the man she’s just slept with, speaking about her elderly parents.
headline.main: The Drama of Aging and Caregiving, on YouTube

abstract: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy of Duke University addresses reader questions about Alzheimer’s disease and other memory problems.
snippet: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy of Duke University addresses reader questions about Alzheimer’s disease and other memory problems.
lead_paragraph: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy, a psychiatry professor at Duke University Medical Center and an author of “The Alzheimer’s Action Plan,” has been answering readers’ questions about Alzheimer’s disease and memory problems. Part 1 of responses can be found here. Part 2, posted below, addresses diagnostic issues, the role played by genetics, causes and policy issues. His last set of answers, about treatment, patient care and new clinical trials, will appear here on Wednesday. [Update: Part 3 can be read here.]

abstract: A 56-year-old man with dementia was admitted to a medical center. His feeding tube needed to be removed from his stomach. It’s a common enough procedure that went fine. But then things went terribly wrong. The culprit: a smartphone.
snippet: A 56-year-old man with dementia was admitted to a medical center. His feeding tube needed to be removed from his stomach. It’s a common enough procedure that went fine. But then things went terribly wrong. The culprit: a smartphone.
lead_paragraph: A 56-year-old man with dementia was admitted to a medical center. His feeding tube needed to be removed from his stomach. It’s a common enough procedure that went fine. But then things went terribly wrong.
headline.main: Multitasking Doctor Imperils Patient, Case Study Says

abstract: Two video portraits of aging parents.
snippet: Two video portraits of aging parents.
lead_paragraph: “I need to have something when she’s gone,” Maggie Steber says as images of her aged mother – looking alternately angry, beatific and simply lost – fill the screen. “Some people write memoirs. We photograph, so we don’t forget.”
headline.main: How They Were, and Where It Ended

abstract: Here are some tips for photographing your loved one now, so you can remember the person you have come to know so intimately over these years of caregiving.
snippet: Here are some tips for photographing your loved one now, so you can remember the person you have come to know so intimately over these years of caregiving.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the realization comes almost too late — you sense that your parents or other loved ones may soon be gone, and it dawns on you that you don’t have any recent photos to remember them by.
headline.main: How to Shoot a Photo to Remember

abstract: Abbott Laboratories said it reached an agreement with the federal government and most states to pay $1.6 billion in connection with its marketing of the anti-seizure drug Depakote.
snippet: Abbott Laboratories said it reached an agreement with the federal government and most states to pay $1.6 billion in connection with its marketing of the anti-seizure drug Depakote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The pharmaceutical company Abbott Laboratories said on Monday that it had reached an agreement with the federal and nearly all state governments to pay $1.6 billion in connection with its illegal marketing of the anti-seizure drug Depakote.

abstract: Families facing a diagnosis of the disease can only ask: Should they live their lives differently, get their affairs in order, join a clinical trial of an experimental drug?
snippet: Families facing a diagnosis of the disease can only ask: Should they live their lives differently, get their affairs in order, join a clinical trial of an experimental drug?
lead_paragraph: When Awilda Jimenez started forgetting things last year, her husband, Edwin, felt a shiver of dread. Her mother had developed Alzheimer’s in her 50s. Could his wife, 61, have it, too?

abstract: Known as the Brahma Bull for his bruising play as an all-American at Georgia Tech and as an 11-year professional, Mr. Morris was named to the N.F.L.’s all-decade team for the 1960s.
snippet: Known as the Brahma Bull for his bruising play as an all-American at Georgia Tech and as an 11-year professional, Mr. Morris was named to the N.F.L.’s all-decade team for the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Larry Morris, the Chicago Bears star linebacker who was named the most valuable player of the 1963 National Football League championship game, in which he stymied Giants quarterback Y. A. Tittle to help give the Bears their first league title in 17 years, died on Wednesday in Austell, Ga., outside Atlanta. He was 79.

abstract: A liberal scholar, Dr. Wink’s views on homosexuality, nonviolence and the nature of Jesus caused many theologians to bridle.
snippet: A liberal scholar, Dr. Wink’s views on homosexuality, nonviolence and the nature of Jesus caused many theologians to bridle.
lead_paragraph: Walter Wink, an influential liberal theologian whose views on homosexuality, nonviolence and the nature of Jesus challenged orthodox interpretations, died on May 10 at his home in Sandisfield, Mass. He was 76.

abstract: Know of an older person who opted for a treatment that, in hindsight, should not have been done? Tell us about it.
snippet: Know of an older person who opted for a treatment that, in hindsight, should not have been done? Tell us about it.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been hearing some sad tales in which the elderly parents of friends and acquaintances have struggled not merely (merely!) with the health problems and disabilities that often accompany aging, but with traumas inadvertently brought on by their own medical decisions.
headline.main: Wanted: Your Thoughts on Unwise Treatments

abstract: The Department of Veterans Affairs will propose new regulations to make it easier for veterans to receive treatment for illnesses linked to traumatic brain injury.
snippet: The Department of Veterans Affairs will propose new regulations to make it easier for veterans to receive treatment for illnesses linked to traumatic brain injury.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Veterans Affairs will propose new regulations on Friday that will make it easier for thousands of veterans to receive health care and compensation for certain illnesses that have been linked to traumatic brain injury.

abstract: In “All Gone” Alex Witchel writes about her mother’s dementia (with recipes), and in “The End of Your Life Book Club” Will Schwalbe describes what he and his mother read as she was dying of cancer.
snippet: In “All Gone” Alex Witchel writes about her mother’s dementia (with recipes), and in “The End of Your Life Book Club” Will Schwalbe describes what he and his mother read as she was dying of cancer.
lead_paragraph: Has “Mommie Dearest” seen its day? To judge by two memoirs by New York insiders, fewer writers have mothers like Joan Crawford — or Momma Rose — than they used to.

abstract: On Super Bowl weekend, we recall the first article about the lasting damage of football injuries.
snippet: On Super Bowl weekend, we recall the first article about the lasting damage of football injuries.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-six years ago, Clark Booth, a young Boston journalist, went to Miami to cover Super Bowl X. Though primarily a television newsman, Booth was on assignment for The Real Paper, an alternative weekly long since closed, for which he often wrote. His plan was to interview the players about the potential consequences of the injuries they suffered playing football.

abstract: A bold research program will test whether a drug can prevent the onset of Alzheimer’s disease well before any symptoms appear.
snippet: A bold research program will test whether a drug can prevent the onset of Alzheimer’s disease well before any symptoms appear.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has announced a bold research program to test whether a drug can prevent the onset of Alzheimer’s disease well before any symptoms appear. It is a long shot, but the payoff could be huge.
headline.main: A New Attack on Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: A New Attack on Alzheimer’s

abstract: Clint Eastwood’s speech bombed, and ageist remarks were quick to follow.
snippet: Clint Eastwood’s speech bombed, and ageist remarks were quick to follow.
lead_paragraph: One advantage of age: I’m old enough to remember the Democratic convention in Atlanta in 1988, when then-Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, deemed a rising young pol making his debut on the national stage, gave a much-anticipated but ultimately disastrous nominating speech for Michael Dukakis.
headline.main: On Ageism and ‘Eastwooding’

abstract: Caring for a fragile husband or wife brings unique stresses.
snippet: Caring for a fragile husband or wife brings unique stresses.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Hadas never had to care for elderly parents; both of hers died quickly, years ago. But in her mental picture of parental caregiving, she envisions the occasional break from responsibility and, especially, someone to commiserate with.
headline.main: Married to the Job

abstract: A study of boxers suggests that an M.R.I. scan could help identify a degenerative brain disorder before a patient develops cognitive problems.
snippet: A study of boxers suggests that an M.R.I. scan could help identify a degenerative brain disorder before a patient develops cognitive problems.
lead_paragraph: A number of football players have been found to have chronic traumatic encephalopathy, but only after posthumous exams.
headline.main: A Promising Brain Test for Football and Other Sports

abstract: Fewer young women complete H.P.V. vaccine, Omega-3 diet may lower Alzheimer’s protein, bending company rules for business travel and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
snippet: Fewer young women complete H.P.V. vaccine, Omega-3 diet may lower Alzheimer’s protein, bending company rules for business travel and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.
headline.main: Tuesday Reading: Fewer Young Women Complete HPV Vaccine

abstract: A clinical trial of Crenezumab will focus largely on members of a Colombian family who are genetically destined to develop the disease but who do not yet have any symptoms.
snippet: A clinical trial of Crenezumab will focus largely on members of a Colombian family who are genetically destined to develop the disease but who do not yet have any symptoms.
lead_paragraph: In a clinical trial that could lead to treatments that prevent Alzheimer’s, people who are genetically guaranteed to develop the disease — but who do not yet have any symptoms — will for the first time be given a drug intended to stop it, federal officials announced Tuesday.

abstract: “Amour” won top prizes at the European Film Awards, boding well for its chances for an Oscar.
snippet: “Amour” won top prizes at the European Film Awards, boding well for its chances for an Oscar.
lead_paragraph: The European Film Awards – a polling of 2,500 professional across the continent – were handed down over the weekend, and it was a near-sweep for Michael Hanecke’s “Amour,” named the best feature. The tale of an elderly Parisian dealing with his wife’s dementia, it also won top prizes for its stars, Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva, and best director for Mr. Haneke, the Austrian filmmaker and frequent Cannes champion best known for “The White Ribbon” and other cinematic tragedies. “Amour” is, as our colleague Larry Rohter wrote, the front-runner for the best foreign-language Oscar.
headline.main: ‘Amour’ Gains a Euro Prize, and Perhaps Momentum

abstract: Government officials announce plans to test a drug to prevent Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Government officials announce plans to test a drug to prevent Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports today that a group of people genetically predisposed to Alzheimer’s disease — but who do not yet have any symptoms — will for the first time be given a drug intended to stop them from developing the condition.
headline.main: A Drug to Prevent Alzheimer’s

abstract: A study shows consumption of omega-3 fatty acids is associated with lower blood levels of beta-amyloid protein, a possible indication of increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: A study shows consumption of omega-3 fatty acids is associated with lower blood levels of beta-amyloid protein, a possible indication of increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that consumption of omega-3 fatty acids, plentiful in fish and nuts, is associated with lower blood levels of beta-amyloid protein.
headline.main: More Omega-3s in Diet, Less of an Alzheimer’s Protein
headline.print_headline: Vital Signs: Nutrition: More Omega-3, Less of a Suspect Protein

abstract: A registry of people willing to participate in Alzheimer’s studies was formed. Its goal: to provide information, raise public awareness, debunk nonsense and help accelerate the pace of research.
snippet: A registry of people willing to participate in Alzheimer’s studies was formed. Its goal: to provide information, raise public awareness, debunk nonsense and help accelerate the pace of research.
lead_paragraph: I just signed up online for the new Alzheimer’s Prevention Registry. It took about three minutes: I entered my name, birth date, gender, ethnicity, e-mail address and answered a few questions about whether I had received a diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment or dementia or had a family history. (I will resist the urge to crack nervous jokes about car keys or whether I will remember the username and password I just created.)
headline.main: Signing Up to Help Fight Alzheimer’s

abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
snippet: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THIS IS HOW YOU LOSE HER,  by Junot Díaz. (Riverhead, $26.95.) The stories in this collection are about love, but they’re also about the undertow of family history and cultural mores, presented in Díaz’s exciting, irresistible and entertaining prose.
headline.main: Editors’ Choice
headline.print_headline: Editors' Choice | Recent Books of Particular Interest

abstract: Imaging has been able to show in living patients the damage Parkinson’s disease causes to two structures deep in the brain, researchers report.
snippet: Imaging has been able to show in living patients the damage Parkinson’s disease causes to two structures deep in the brain, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology report, brain imaging has been able to show in living patients the progressive damage Parkinson’s disease causes to two small structures deep in the brain.

abstract: Making vegan food the new normal, Google working on maps for iPhone and iPad, some New York schools provide morning-after pills and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
snippet: Making vegan food the new normal, Google working on maps for iPhone and iPad, some New York schools provide morning-after pills and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.
headline.main: Wednesday Reading: Making Vegan Food the New Normal

abstract: Evidence suggests that Alzheimer’s might be another form of diabetes, and links both to the overconsumption of junk food.
snippet: Evidence suggests that Alzheimer’s might be another form of diabetes, and links both to the overconsumption of junk food.
lead_paragraph: Just in case you need another reason to cut back on junk food, it now turns out that Alzheimer’s could well be a form of diet-induced diabetes. That’s the bad news. The good news is that laying off soda, doughnuts, processed meats and fries could allow you to keep your mind intact until your body fails you.
headline.main: Is Alzheimer’s Type 3 Diabetes?

abstract: Critics in Los Angeles, New York and Boston vote for films with gravitas, though they’re far from a consensus.
snippet: Critics in Los Angeles, New York and Boston vote for films with gravitas, though they’re far from a consensus.
lead_paragraph: The films that, at year’s end, critics (and sometimes audiences) love are beginning to take shape and let’s call it, well, whatever form gravitas takes. The Los Angeles Film Critics Association announced its choices over the weekend, and it gave the top prize to Michael Haneke’s “Amour,” the story of an elderly French couple dealing with dementia and death.
headline.main: Critics’ Groups in Los Angeles, New York and Boston Get Serious

abstract: Wooden Indian Burial Ground, a guitar-bass-drums band from Portland, Ore., embraces 1960s garage psychedelia to particularly molten effect.
snippet: Wooden Indian Burial Ground, a guitar-bass-drums band from Portland, Ore., embraces 1960s garage psychedelia to particularly molten effect.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1981, when the CMJ Music Marathon started, 1960s garage psychedelia was already an antique genre being enthusiastically revived by fuzz-tone-loving aficionados. I can’t think of a CMJ (or for that matter South By Southwest) where I haven’t thoroughly enjoyed some band plunging into the hopped-up stomps, overamped blues riffs, drones and freakouts so fondly remembered by bands that have been, in more recent years, too young to have possibly witnessed the original excesses.

abstract: In “an example of social networking in science,” data from more than 100 centers identified genes that play a role in intelligence and memory.
snippet: In “an example of social networking in science,” data from more than 100 centers identified genes that play a role in intelligence and memory.
lead_paragraph: In the largest collaborative study of the brain to date, scientists using imaging technology at more than 100 centers worldwide have for the first time zeroed in on genes that they agree play a role in intelligence and memory.
headline.main: Crowd-Sourcing Expands Power of Brain Research
headline.print_headline: Crowd-Sourcing Expands Power of Brain Research

abstract: People put up with hearing loss for up to 10 years before doing something about it, one expert says.
snippet: People put up with hearing loss for up to 10 years before doing something about it, one expert says.
lead_paragraph: While visiting my parents recently, I overheard a conversation between them that went something like this.
headline.main: Why Won’t They Get Hearing Aids?

abstract: A small study shows promise that could lead to clues to encoding memory and treating neurological diseases.
snippet: A small study shows promise that could lead to clues to encoding memory and treating neurological diseases.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have for the first time improved memory by applying direct electrical stimulation to a key area in the brain as it learns its way around a new environment.

abstract: After 15 years as archbishop, Cardinal Bevilacqua saw his accomplishments tarnished by accusations that he covered up sexual abuse by priests.
snippet: After 15 years as archbishop, Cardinal Bevilacqua saw his accomplishments tarnished by accusations that he covered up sexual abuse by priests.
lead_paragraph: Anthony J. Bevilacqua, a former cardinal and archbishop of Philadelphia whose passion for Roman Catholic causes like helping the poor and fighting abortion was eclipsed in retirement by accusations that he had covered up sexual abuse by priests, died on Tuesday at a seminary in Wynnewood, Pa. He was 88.

abstract: Researchers found evidence of long-term degeneration in the brains of athletes, including John Mackey and Derek Boogaard, military veterans and others.
snippet: Researchers found evidence of long-term degeneration in the brains of athletes, including John Mackey and Derek Boogaard, military veterans and others.
lead_paragraph: The growing evidence of a link between head trauma and long-term, degenerative brain disease was amplified in an extensive study of athletes, military veterans and others who absorbed repeated hits to the head, according to new findings published in the scientific journal Brain.

abstract: Junot Díaz discusses “This Is How You Lose Her,” his new book of stories.
snippet: Junot Díaz discusses “This Is How You Lose Her,” his new book of stories.
lead_paragraph: In the New York Times Book Review, Leah Hager Cohen reviews Junot Díaz’s “This Is How You Lose Her,” a collection of stories that brings back Yunior, the narrator of several earlier stories by Mr. Díaz and a character in his Pulitzer Prize-winning novel “The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao.” Ms. Cohen writes:

abstract: The Wartburg Adult Care Community in Mount Vernon is planning more affordable housing units, a new elderly day care center and expanded efforts to help older people remain in their homes.
snippet: The Wartburg Adult Care Community in Mount Vernon is planning more affordable housing units, a new elderly day care center and expanded efforts to help older people remain in their homes.
lead_paragraph: ON a fixed income, Antonio and Nan LaGuidice struggle to meet the $1,700-a-month rent for their two-bedroom apartment in New Rochelle, and the costs of doctor visits, cancer treatments and medication that Mrs. LaGuidice, 72, requires. The couple, who share their place with an adult daughter, manage only by cutting costs so close to the bone that Mr. LaGuidice, 90, a former building superintendent and school bus driver who needs a hearing aid, cannot spare the money for one.

abstract: “Flight” is a play about memory, what it can reveal, and the difficulty of clinging to what remains of it.
snippet: “Flight” is a play about memory, what it can reveal, and the difficulty of clinging to what remains of it.
lead_paragraph: Were it just another weak and underwritten play, “Flight” might be easy to dismiss. Yet because it trafficks in unearned emotions by exploiting the Holocaust, Alzheimer’s disease and dementia, the story treads close to being objectionable as well as ineffective.

abstract: With the legendary coach Pat Summitt dealing with early onset dementia, Tennessee has to face its usual expectations as well as the question of whether this will be Summitt’s last season.
snippet: With the legendary coach Pat Summitt dealing with early onset dementia, Tennessee has to face its usual expectations as well as the question of whether this will be Summitt’s last season.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — Pat Summitt plays games and puzzles on her iPad to help her remain alert. Her sense of humor remains acute, along with her ambition to win a ninth national championship. But anyone who has been around her can sense inevitable changes seven months after Summitt revealed that she had symptoms of early onset Alzheimer’s disease.

abstract: A variation on elder care: moving in with an ex.
snippet: A variation on elder care: moving in with an ex.
lead_paragraph: She had recently moved to beautiful San Francisco from the East Coast. He was an artist living in the old Victorian house she was sketching. He came outside, looked over her shoulder and pointed out that she hadn’t drawn the correct number of pillars.
headline.main: The Ex Factor

abstract: So often, I hear people say they would rather die than get Alzheimer’s. But my grandmother showed me that we are more than the sum of our memories.
snippet: So often, I hear people say they would rather die than get Alzheimer’s. But my grandmother showed me that we are more than the sum of our memories.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, when my grandmother JoAnn was first diagnosed with Alzheimer’s, the news sent me into a tailspin of fear and sadness.
headline.main: Finding Joy in Alzheimer’s

abstract: Some people may be thinking of second careers, while others hope to forestall the mental declines of age.
snippet: Some people may be thinking of second careers, while others hope to forestall the mental declines of age.
lead_paragraph: MORE and more retired people are heading back to the nearest classroom — as students and, in some cases, teachers — and they are finding out that school can be lovelier the second time around. Some may be thinking of second careers, but most just want to keep their minds stimulated, learn something new or catch up with a subject they were always curious about but never had time for.

lead_paragraph: Balancing a violin and bow in one hand, Concetta Previte whipped her wheelchair through a Bronx nursing home, heading for a composing workshop at the Institute for Music and Neurologic Function.

abstract: The suit, filed Wednesday in state court in Manhattan, is part of a tangle of art deals that led to two earlier lawsuits against the dealer in federal court, one of which Mr. Gagosian settled for $4.4 million last year, according to court papers.
snippet: The suit, filed Wednesday in state court in Manhattan, is part of a tangle of art deals that led to two earlier lawsuits against the dealer in federal court, one of which Mr. Gagosian settled for $4.4 million last year, according to court papers.
lead_paragraph: A prominent art collector has sued the dealer Larry Gagosian, claiming that he sold a 1964 Roy Lichtenstein painting from her collection without her consent. The suit, filed Wednesday in state court in Manhattan, is part of a tangle of art deals that led to two earlier lawsuits against the dealer in federal court, one of which Mr. Gagosian settled for $4.4 million last year, according to court papers.
headline.main: Gagosian Sued for Selling Lichtenstein Painting Without Owner’s Consent

abstract: Research on people who speak three or more languages, as millions do in India, is scarce.
snippet: Research on people who speak three or more languages, as millions do in India, is scarce.
lead_paragraph: “Being bilingual, it turns out, makes you smarter,” Yudhijit Bhattacharjee writes in an op-ed in The New York Times. “It can have a profound effect on your brain, improving cognitive skills not related to language and even shielding against dementia in old age.”
headline.main: If Bilingual Is Good, Is Trilingual Better?

abstract: Steve James’s film “Head Games” examines the long-term consequences of some high-impact sports.
snippet: Steve James’s film “Head Games” examines the long-term consequences of some high-impact sports.
lead_paragraph: Part of the romance of sports lies in the thrill of controlled, heroic brutality. Modern athletes are often likened to warriors: they sacrifice, put their bodies on the line and take punishment in pursuit of a noble cause. The rest of us — couch potatoes, season-ticket holders, parents on the sidelines — cheer for the toughest players and the hardest hits.

abstract: A history professor at Princeton University uncovers dark tales of caregiving in the decades before America’s social safety net.
snippet: A history professor at Princeton University uncovers dark tales of caregiving in the decades before America’s social safety net.
lead_paragraph: In the decades before Social Security and Medicare began providing financial support to the elderly, many Americans entered the later stages of life — threatened by disease, dementia and disability — unsure of who would care for them. Sometimes, they persuaded children, younger relatives or neighbors to take on the responsibilities with promises of compensation: care for me when I’m old, the bargain went, and I will leave you the house. Or the farm, or the shop, or the bank account.
headline.main: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: Broken Promises

abstract: More of the very elderly are dying in their homes, not hospitals, according to a new report.
snippet: More of the very elderly are dying in their homes, not hospitals, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: Always alert for a bit of good news about the sorry way so many older Americans die, I noticed a recent report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The agency’s statisticians looked at the deaths of people over 85 — 700,000 of them in 2007 — and where they occurred, and pointed out some encouraging trends.
headline.main: Where the Oldest Die Now

abstract: Studies find that the cumulative use of drugs that are among dozens of common painkillers, antihistamines and psychiatric medications has been linked to cognitive impairment.
snippet: Studies find that the cumulative use of drugs that are among dozens of common painkillers, antihistamines and psychiatric medications has been linked to cognitive impairment.
lead_paragraph: Many people are unaware that dozens of painkillers, antihistamines and psychiatric medications — from drugstore staples to popular antidepressants — can adversely affect brain function, mostly in the elderly. Regular use of multiple medications that have this effect has been linked to cognitive impairment and memory loss.
headline.main: Cocktail of Popular Drugs May Cloud Brain

abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
snippet: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SO MUCH PRETTY,  by Cara Hoffman (Simon & Schuster, $16.) The disappearance of a local waitress foments an atmosphere of paranoia in an upstate New York town in Hoffman’s first novel, which addresses rural poverty, domestic abuse, teenage violence and pollution. Over the course of 17 years, the story moves among the town’s inhabitants, many of whom remain willfully blind to the deeper causes of the tragedy.
headline.main: Paperback Row

abstract: Pharmacists responsible for reviewing the medication of patients in California nursing homes routinely allowed inappropriate and potentially lethal prescriptions of antipsychotic medications.
snippet: Pharmacists responsible for reviewing the medication of patients in California nursing homes routinely allowed inappropriate and potentially lethal prescriptions of antipsychotic medications.
lead_paragraph: A woman with a medical history of seizures was prescribed the antipsychotic drug Seroquel, despite research showing that elderly people who take antipsychotic drugs are more likely to experience seizures. She was also given the antidepressant Trazodone, which has been linked to an increase in seizures among older patients. And then, according to a recent investigation by the California Department of Public Health, the woman was given a second antipsychotic drug, Risperdal. The combination of the two antipsychotic medications, the investigators said, could cause “life-threatening arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats).”

abstract: Meryl Streep is heavily tipped to pick up the best actress award at Sunday’s Oscar ceremonies for her portrayal of Margaret Thatcher, the former British prime minister, in the movie “The Iron Lady”. But what of the real woman – and her handbag?
snippet: Meryl Streep is heavily tipped to pick up the best actress award at Sunday’s Oscar ceremonies for her portrayal of Margaret Thatcher, the former British prime minister, in the movie “The Iron Lady”. But what of the real woman – and her handbag?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I invented Margaret Thatcher’s handbag.

abstract: Gordie Howe will be back at the Pacific Coliseum, in Vancouver, British Columbia, on Friday for the annual Gordie Howe night.
snippet: Gordie Howe will be back at the Pacific Coliseum, in Vancouver, British Columbia, on Friday for the annual Gordie Howe night.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Gordie Howe is only 80 days older than the cornerstone of Ron Toigo’s business empire. First, Howe endorsed the Triple O burgers from the White Spot restaurant chain, which began in 1928, and then he bought into Toigo’s Vancouver Giants, of the Western Hockey League, in 2001.
headline.main: In Vancouver, a Night for Gordie Howe

abstract: The documentary filmmaker who recorded the Saints’ defensive coordinator said parents of children who play football had to “pay attention to the influence of men who will sacrifice their kids for W’s.”
snippet: The documentary filmmaker who recorded the Saints’ defensive coordinator said parents of children who play football had to “pay attention to the influence of men who will sacrifice their kids for W’s.”
lead_paragraph: “Every single one of you, before you get off the pile, affect the head. Early, affect the head. Continue, touch and hit the head.”— Gregg Williams, the former Saints defensive coordinator, caught on tape,  exhorting his players to injure the 49ers a day before their playoff game. (In the video above, Williams was Washington’s defensive coordinator when the Redskins “affected” Peyton Manning’s head and neck.)
headline.main: Release of Gregg Williams Tape Was Warning to Parents

abstract: For people who don’t want to leave their homes, a smattering of continuing care retirement communities offer services “without walls,” but experts say the concept may be poised to expand more broadly in the years ahead.
snippet: For people who don’t want to leave their homes, a smattering of continuing care retirement communities offer services “without walls,” but experts say the concept may be poised to expand more broadly in the years ahead.
lead_paragraph: For 51 years, Catherine Mack has lived in a four-bedroom house in Haddon Township, N.J. Even at age 96, she has no intention of leaving.
headline.main: A Choice of Community Care, in Your Own Home

snippet: In Stéphane Robelin’s “All Together” five septuagenarian friends (including one played by Jane Fonda, in first role in a French film since 1972) share a house.
lead_paragraph: “It’s strange. We plan for everything. We insure our cars, our homes. We even insure our lives. But we don’t give a thought to our final years.”

abstract: Some of Retha Walden Gambaro’s sculptures are on view through May 13 in an exhibition at the Heard Museum’s new sculpture garden in Phoenix.
snippet: Some of Retha Walden Gambaro’s sculptures are on view through May 13 in an exhibition at the Heard Museum’s new sculpture garden in Phoenix.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Some of the American Indian artworks at the Heard Museum date back a century or more, while others are brand-new, brought here along bumpy reservation roads just last month or last year.

abstract: Mr. Carey was an underappreciated cog in the powerful Yankees machine of the 1950s that won four consecutive American League pennants and two World Series.
snippet: Mr. Carey was an underappreciated cog in the powerful Yankees machine of the 1950s that won four consecutive American League pennants and two World Series.
lead_paragraph: Andy Carey, an underappreciated cog in the powerful Yankees machine of the 1950s that won four consecutive American League pennants and two World Series, died on Dec. 15 at his home in Costa Mesa, Calif. He was 80.

abstract: A series of e-mails from Gagosian Gallery provide a glimpse into the sale of a Lichtenstein painting that is at the center of a dispute between the gallery and the artwork’s former owner.
snippet: A series of e-mails from Gagosian Gallery provide a glimpse into the sale of a Lichtenstein painting that is at the center of a dispute between the gallery and the artwork’s former owner.
lead_paragraph: Of the adjectives often used to describe the art market — complex, unregulated and opaque — the last has always been truest. Glimpses into negotiations between high-end galleries and collectors are rare. But a lawsuit in state court in Manhattan is providing a view into the dealings of not just any gallery, but the world’s most successful one, owned by Larry Gagosian.

abstract: The device gives researchers a model for how to support and enhance fairly advanced mental skills in the frontal cortex of brain, the seat of thinking and planning.
snippet: The device gives researchers a model for how to support and enhance fairly advanced mental skills in the frontal cortex of brain, the seat of thinking and planning.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have designed a brain implant that sharpened decision making and restored lost mental capacity in monkeys, providing the first demonstration in primates of the sort of brain prosthesis that could eventually help people with damage from dementia, strokes or other brain injuries.
headline.main: Brain Implant Improves Thinking in Monkeys, First Such Demonstration in Primates
headline.print_headline: Brain Implant Improves Thinking in Monkeys, First Such Demonstration in Primates

abstract: “Without his invention we’d still be getting only black-and-white pictures from our digital cameras,” an industry expert said.
snippet: “Without his invention we’d still be getting only black-and-white pictures from our digital cameras,” an industry expert said.
lead_paragraph: Bryce Bayer, a retired Eastman Kodak research scientist who invented the checkerboard-like filter that has allowed millions of digital cameras to capture vivid color images, died on Nov. 13 in Bath, Me. He was 83.

abstract: Commissioner Roger Goodell told an audience at the Harvard School of Public Health that the N.F.L. was working hard to combat serious injuries, including those from hits to the head.
snippet: Commissioner Roger Goodell told an audience at the Harvard School of Public Health that the N.F.L. was working hard to combat serious injuries, including those from hits to the head.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Thursday that the league was doing more than ever to combat serious injuries, including those from hits to the head that can cause brain trauma, but that a cultural shift was needed to change the “warrior mentality” of players unwilling to disclose when they are hurt.

abstract: The more researchers learn about delirium, the clearer it is that attention must be paid.
snippet: The more researchers learn about delirium, the clearer it is that attention must be paid.
lead_paragraph: The more researchers learn about delirium, the clearer it is that attention must be paid. For years, people thought of it as a transient condition: Patients, especially older ones, grow confused and irrational and sometimes even violent during hospital stays — then in a few days, the delirium passes and people return to themselves.
headline.main: Effects of Delirium Are Found to Linger

abstract: The frolicsome comedy “5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche” at SoHo Playhouse seems destined to attract a cult following.
snippet: The frolicsome comedy “5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche” at SoHo Playhouse seems destined to attract a cult following.
lead_paragraph: Let it be said henceforth that a quiche is nothing to sneeze at. Oh, I know, you’ve always thought of quiches as silly cuisine, fit to be served only at that silliest of meals, brunch. How wrong you were. A quiche is a mighty thing, as powerful and blessed as womanhood itself.

abstract: More Americans older than 55 are being imprisoned, and many prisons are unprepared to provide them with health care, Human Rights Watch said in a new report.
snippet: More Americans older than 55 are being imprisoned, and many prisons are unprepared to provide them with health care, Human Rights Watch said in a new report.
lead_paragraph: The number of Americans in prison older than 55 is growing at a faster rate than the group’s share of the population at large, and many prisons are unprepared to provide them with health care, which can cost as much as nine times more than for younger inmates, Human Rights Watch said in a report released Friday.

abstract: Mamie Gummer plays a young doctor in “Emily Owens, M.D.,” a new show whose premise is that working in a hospital is like being back in high school.
snippet: Mamie Gummer plays a young doctor in “Emily Owens, M.D.,” a new show whose premise is that working in a hospital is like being back in high school.
lead_paragraph: Did someone call for a young female doctor? Apparently so, because Mindy Kaling (“The Mindy Project”) and Jordana Spiro (“The Mob Doctor”) have already shown up this fall, joining Rachel Bilson (“Hart of Dixie”), who’s still hanging around from last season. Now it’s a quartet with the arrival of Mamie Gummer in “Emily Owens, M.D.,” making its debut on Tuesday night on CW.

abstract: The columnist Ellen Goodman has introduced a Web site encouraging people to discuss their end-of-life wishes — before it’s too late.
snippet: The columnist Ellen Goodman has introduced a Web site encouraging people to discuss their end-of-life wishes — before it’s too late.
lead_paragraph: Among the many things that Ellen Goodman has done — written a widely syndicated column, published books, won a Pulitzer Prize for commentary, given probably hundreds of talks on topics from friendship and feminism to bioethics — is this familiar job: She’s been a family caregiver.
headline.main: How Do You Want It to End?

abstract: We have consulted marriage counselors and geriatricians to find out what caregivers — either grown children or one of the spouses involved– can do to help restore peace and balance to the relationship when a good marriage goes bad.
snippet: We have consulted marriage counselors and geriatricians to find out what caregivers — either grown children or one of the spouses involved– can do to help restore peace and balance to the relationship when a good marriage goes bad.
lead_paragraph: A post on Monday discussed the forces that can make an older couple’s good marriage suddenly go bad — an array of subtle, and often-misunderstood, mental, physical and emotional factors that can upset the equilibrium of even the happiest marriages.
headline.main: In the Middle: Helping Unhappy Couples

abstract: Government agencies knew about deaths from strangling on bed rails for years, but did little to address the issue.
snippet: Government agencies knew about deaths from strangling on bed rails for years, but did little to address the issue.
lead_paragraph: In November 2006, when Clara Marshall began suffering from the effects of dementia, her family moved her into the Waterford at Fairway Village, an assisted living home in Vancouver, Wash. The facility offered round-the-clock care for Ms. Marshall, who had wandered away from home several times. Her husband, Dan, 80 years old at the time, felt he could no longer care for her alone.

abstract: “Detachment,” from Tony Kaye, is a close-up on high school life and dysfunctional families.
snippet: “Detachment,” from Tony Kaye, is a close-up on high school life and dysfunctional families.
lead_paragraph: “Detachment,” the latest provocation from Tony Kaye, the director of the neo-Nazi drama “American History X” and the graphic abortion documentary “Lake of Fire,” belongs to a subset of shockers that know exactly which nerves to prick to produce intense reactions. Like-minded movies determined to blow the lid off your complacency include Larry Clark’s “Kids” and Darren Aronofsky’s “Requiem for a Dream.” But how much can you trust films that blend high-minded outrage with a tabloid-savvy sensationalism?

abstract: In an era when fierce infections like MRSA and Clostridium difficile haunt nursing homes and hospitals, the percentage of nursing homes cited for deficiencies in “hand hygiene” has been rising.
snippet: In an era when fierce infections like MRSA and Clostridium difficile haunt nursing homes and hospitals, the percentage of nursing homes cited for deficiencies in “hand hygiene” has been rising.
lead_paragraph: This sounds like common sense: If you work in a nursing home, you wash your hands when you start your shift and again before you leave. You wash your hands (or, in some cases, use an alcohol-based antimicrobial) before and after any direct contact with residents. Before you help someone with tooth-brushing, bathing, eating or using the toilet. Before and after handling a catheter or taking a finger-stick blood sample or changing a dressing. Or handling used bed linens. Or blowing your own nose.
headline.main: The Dirty Little Secret of Nursing Homes

abstract: Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan agreed on many issues, but newly published documents show how the two strong allies butted heads over Britain’s 1982 Falklands war with Argentina.
snippet: Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan agreed on many issues, but newly published documents show how the two strong allies butted heads over Britain’s 1982 Falklands war with Argentina.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The bond between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Ronald Reagan, both in office in the 1980s, has become a kind of gold standard, showing what the “special relationship” between Britain and the United States can be when their leaders share a political creed.
