abstract: Mr. Anderson was known for his children’s show “Thunderbirds,” but he also was a force behind more grown-up fare like “Space 1999.”
snippet: Mr. Anderson was known for his children’s show “Thunderbirds,” but he also was a force behind more grown-up fare like “Space 1999.”
lead_paragraph: Gerry Anderson, a British filmmaker who transformed old-fashioned puppets into futuristic action heroes in the 1960s in the hugely popular children’s show “Thunderbirds,” and later cast real people in series including  “U.F.O.” and “Space: 1999,” died on Wednesday in Oxfordshire, England. He was 83.

abstract: Opera Theater of St. Louis and Jazz St. Louis have commissioned an opera by Terence Blanchard based on the life of the boxer Emile Griffith, whose battering of Benny Paret in 1962 resulted in Paret’s death.
snippet: Opera Theater of St. Louis and Jazz St. Louis have commissioned an opera by Terence Blanchard based on the life of the boxer Emile Griffith, whose battering of Benny Paret in 1962 resulted in Paret’s death.
lead_paragraph: The grainy black and white footage is chilling.

abstract: Dave Duerson’s son Tregg sued the N.F.L. on Thursday, contending that its handling of his father’s concussions led to his brain damage and ultimate suicide.
snippet: Dave Duerson’s son Tregg sued the N.F.L. on Thursday, contending that its handling of his father’s concussions led to his brain damage and ultimate suicide.
lead_paragraph: A year after the former N.F.L. star Dave Duerson shot himself in the chest and requested that his brain be used to research the sport’s long-term risks, his son Tregg sued the league Thursday in state court in Chicago, contending that the N.F.L.’s handling of Duerson’s on-field concussions led to his brain damage and ultimate suicide.

abstract: Andrew Hawkins was a down-on-his-luck day trader in 2008 when, convinced he was being watched, he stole a vehicle and found an unexpected passenger in his back seat.
snippet: Andrew Hawkins was a down-on-his-luck day trader in 2008 when, convinced he was being watched, he stole a vehicle and found an unexpected passenger in his back seat.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Hawkins was 36 and, to strangers, probably looked fine. Articulate, living with his girlfriend in an Upper East Side apartment, he was a freelance investor and budding day trader.

abstract: In “12.21” a doctor and a Maya scholar join forces to save the world from a sudden collapse, one foreshadowed by the puzzling demise of ancient Maya civilizations.
snippet: In “12.21” a doctor and a Maya scholar join forces to save the world from a sudden collapse, one foreshadowed by the puzzling demise of ancient Maya civilizations.
lead_paragraph: Dustin Thomason begins “12.21” with a prologue in which a mysterious ancient figure pricks his arm, draws blood and then begins writing what may become “the most valuable artifact in the history of Mesoamerican studies.” In the genre to which this book belongs — thrillers Dan Brown could write with a reanimated Michael Crichton, which, given the emphasis on weird science, is not out of the question — this is just the author’s way of saying hello.

abstract: Blacks are much more likely to elect aggressive care, and decline do-not-resuscitate orders than whites, but once given palliative care consultation, their preferences are significantly different.
snippet: Blacks are much more likely to elect aggressive care, and decline do-not-resuscitate orders than whites, but once given palliative care consultation, their preferences are significantly different.
lead_paragraph: The family seated opposite me is tense. Having met at the bedside of a critically ill patient only moments earlier, we have gathered in a quiet alcove next to the intensive care unit to discuss what can only be bad news.

abstract: The Hungarian director Bela Tarr’s black-and-white film “The Turin Horse” (he has said it’s last) is a thorough and systematic statement of intellectual despair.
snippet: The Hungarian director Bela Tarr’s black-and-white film “The Turin Horse” (he has said it’s last) is a thorough and systematic statement of intellectual despair.
lead_paragraph: The Hungarian director Bela Tarr has said that “The Turin Horse,” his ninth feature, will be his last film. Could he change his mind? He is only 56, part of a generational cohort of filmmakers that includes Spike Lee, Olivier Assayas and the Coen brothers, who all retain an aura of youthfulness in middle age.

abstract: By studying chicken embryos in the bedroom of her house in Turin, Italy, Dr. Levi-Montalcini discovered how embryo cells built a latticework of intricate connections.
snippet: By studying chicken embryos in the bedroom of her house in Turin, Italy, Dr. Levi-Montalcini discovered how embryo cells built a latticework of intricate connections.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rita Levi-Montalcini, a Nobel Prize-winning neurologist who discovered critical chemical tools that the body uses to direct cell growth and build nerve networks, opening the way for the study of how those processes can go wrong in diseases like dementia and cancer, died on Sunday at her home in Rome. She was 103.

abstract: We know more about concussions than we used to, but even the best helmets can’t prevent them.
snippet: We know more about concussions than we used to, but even the best helmets can’t prevent them.
lead_paragraph: THE beating goes on. This past Saturday a Tulane University football player, Devon Walker, collided with a teammate while making a tackle. Walker, who is 21, broke his neck. Fans gasped. Doctors performed C.P.R. He may or may not walk again.

abstract: Michael Wolff’s mother and the link between life extension and euthanasia.
snippet: Michael Wolff’s mother and the link between life extension and euthanasia.
lead_paragraph: The provocation of the week is the media impresario Michael Wolff’s New York magazine account of his mother’s long, agonizing dying process, a piece that moves inexorably from a compelling case against hyper-interventionist medicine (“what I feel most intensely when I sit by my mother’s bed is a crushing sense of guilt for keeping her alive”) to a case for assisted suicide (“give us the right to make provisions for when we want to go … “) to a case for straightforward euthanasia (“what I would not do for a fair-minded body to whom I might plead for my mother’s end”). It concludes with a promise that his generation will do these things differently when their time comes:
headline.main: The Boomer Quietus

abstract: Tennessee’s Southeastern Championship gave everyone a chance to appreciate what Coach Pat Summitt has done in women’s basketball.
snippet: Tennessee’s Southeastern Championship gave everyone a chance to appreciate what Coach Pat Summitt has done in women’s basketball.
lead_paragraph: Were this a normal season, the sight of the Tennessee women’s team winning a Southeastern Conference championship would strike everyone as so normal it would hardly be worth a lingering look. Were this a normal season, the questions would have immediately gone to whether the Lady Vols were primed for another national championship. And, were this a normal season, Coach Pat Summitt would have stayed on the sideline beaming as her players climbed the ladder to cut down the nets and soak up the adulation.
headline.main: Leading Off: A Glorious Climb for Pat Summitt

abstract: Sales of medications that target symptoms of normal aging are soaring, according to data recently released at the American Public Health Association’s annual meeting.
snippet: Sales of medications that target symptoms of normal aging are soaring, according to data recently released at the American Public Health Association’s annual meeting.
lead_paragraph: We wrinkle. We have night sweats. We forget names and wake, with brittle, unwanted consciousness, in the middle of the night.

abstract: The Alzheimer’s drug Aricept 23 was set to lose its patent, but its makers received approval for a higher dosage that extended their exclusivity.
snippet: The Alzheimer’s drug Aricept 23 was set to lose its patent, but its makers received approval for a higher dosage that extended their exclusivity.
lead_paragraph: Four months before a best-selling Alzheimer’s drug was set to lose its patent protection, its makers received approval for a higher dosage that extended their exclusive right to sell the drug. But the higher dosage caused potentially dangerous side effects and worked only slightly better than the existing drugs, according to an article published Thursday in the British Medical Journal.

abstract: Lying, hiding, cheating.
snippet: Lying, hiding, cheating.
lead_paragraph: My mother has been having memory issues for a number of years. Her neurologist has been telling her it is “mild dementia.” Her cognitive impairment and memory loss have worsened, and I recently met the neurologist without her. He told me that she has Alzheimer’s. He felt we should not yet tell my mother, as that diagnosis has been her greatest fear and it would be too devastating. He felt we could not tell my father unless we told my mother. I am uncomfortable keeping this terrible secret. Is it better to tell a loved one of the prognosis they fear, or is it more ethical to let them live in hopes that they have escaped it? NAME WITHHELD

abstract: Spending cuts favored by Republicans would not simply reduce commitments not covered by projected revenues, but would shift them to individuals and families, an economist writes.
snippet: Spending cuts favored by Republicans would not simply reduce commitments not covered by projected revenues, but would shift them to individuals and families, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.
headline.main: The Unfunded Liabilities You Love

abstract: Another study adds to evidence suggesting that hospital stays are linked to cognitive difficulty in elderly patients.
snippet: Another study adds to evidence suggesting that hospital stays are linked to cognitive difficulty in elderly patients.
lead_paragraph: Many older people fear that a hospital stay could leave them even more disabled than they were before. Unfortunately, there’s new reason to believe this fear is justified. Elderly patients who are hospitalized are at much higher risk of cognitive problems afterward, according to a study published on Wednesday in the journal Neurology.
headline.main: After Hospitalization, Mental Trouble for Elderly Patients

abstract: The bloody end of the Kansas City Chiefs linebacker Jovan Belcher raises broader questions about the destructive culture of pro football.
snippet: The bloody end of the Kansas City Chiefs linebacker Jovan Belcher raises broader questions about the destructive culture of pro football.
lead_paragraph: Pro football left me with a neck injury. Watching pro football, I mean. At least three of the games that started at 1 p.m. Eastern time on Sunday went thrillingly down to the wire, two of them bleeding into overtime, and as I sat in a sports bar jerking my gaze from the television showing the Colts to the one with the Seahawks to the one with the Rams, I suffered mild whiplash. I ache as I write.

abstract: The United States Preventive Services Task Force declined on Monday to recommend hearing tests for older adults without symptoms of hearing loss.
snippet: The United States Preventive Services Task Force declined on Monday to recommend hearing tests for older adults without symptoms of hearing loss.
lead_paragraph: Hearing tests are cheap and effective. There are no known health harms. And they can identify older adults with compromised hearing who might benefit from using a hearing aid.
keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Ears and Hearing', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Elder Care', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Preventive Medicine', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'organizations', 'value': 'United States Preventive Services Task Force', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
headline.main: ‘Insufficient’ Evidence for Routine Hearing Tests, Experts Say

abstract: Could the brain autopsy of a 27-year-old former Marine who did two tours in Iraq help explain the rash of suicides and other troubles among so many veterans?
snippet: Could the brain autopsy of a 27-year-old former Marine who did two tours in Iraq help explain the rash of suicides and other troubles among so many veterans?
lead_paragraph: He was a 27-year-old former Marine, struggling to adjust to civilian life after two tours in Iraq. Once an A student, he now found himself unable to remember conversations, dates and routine bits of daily life. He became irritable, snapped at his children and withdrew from his family. He and his wife began divorce proceedings.

abstract: A total of four overtimes in the four playoff games on Thursday made for an interesting night in the N.H.L.
snippet: A total of four overtimes in the four playoff games on Thursday made for an interesting night in the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: If the N.H.L. is good for anything — aside from its cottage industry in defining which skull-rattling hits are dangerous and which are just boys being boys — it is good for taking up time. Yes, it has a season that is best measured by the geologic time scale. Yes, its playoffs are so long the Stanley Cup champions have no idea whom they played in the first round. And so, on the second day of the playoffs, why not have four overtimes?

abstract: For two weeks, the family of Marie Salatino did not know where she had been taken or if she was even alive.
snippet: For two weeks, the family of Marie Salatino did not know where she had been taken or if she was even alive.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks of anxious searching led Paul J. DiViesti to the entrance of a nursing-home dining room in Brooklyn on Tuesday morning. Inside, lines of hospital beds stretched across the linoleum floor, divided by white cloth screens. When he spied a long gray ponytail emerging from a figure curled up under a thin blanket, he knew the search for his grandmother had ended.

abstract: Americans are increasingly aware of the dangers of noise but less aware of how it further handicaps those who already have hearing loss.
snippet: Americans are increasingly aware of the dangers of noise but less aware of how it further handicaps those who already have hearing loss.
lead_paragraph: “NO one told me it was going to be this noisy,” says a young woman who is going deaf in Nina Raines’s play “Tribes.” If you have a hearing aid, the world is, paradoxically, far noisier than it is for a person with normal hearing. The human ear is a miraculous thing. It can filter out the roar at Madison Square Garden while homing in on the voice of the person in the next seat. A hearing aid can’t do that. The only way to really filter out noise is simply to turn it off.

abstract: Amid the worst hurricane to hit New York City in nearly 80 years, officials have claimed that the Promenade Rehabilitation and Health Care Center failed to provide the most basic care to its patients.
snippet: Amid the worst hurricane to hit New York City in nearly 80 years, officials have claimed that the Promenade Rehabilitation and Health Care Center failed to provide the most basic care to its patients.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy announced itself by tossing a section of Boardwalk against the Promenade nursing home in Rockaway Park, Queens, blowing out its windows and sending waves washing through the first floor.

abstract: A mutation to a gene, TREM2, is suspected of interfering with the brain’s ability to prevent the buildup of toxic shards of a protein that accumulate in plaques on the brain.
snippet: A mutation to a gene, TREM2, is suspected of interfering with the brain’s ability to prevent the buildup of toxic shards of a protein that accumulate in plaques on the brain.
lead_paragraph: Alzheimer’s researchers and drug companies have for years concentrated on one hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease: the production of toxic shards of a protein that accumulate in plaques on the brain.

abstract: A trendy hotel, a play about menopausal women, a foray into fashion and an art show present the Out of Towner with some food for thought.
snippet: A trendy hotel, a play about menopausal women, a foray into fashion and an art show present the Out of Towner with some food for thought.
lead_paragraph: DARKNESS fell on a brisk Saturday night, and droves of the young and the raucous flooded the entrance and lobby of the Dream Downtown hotel in Chelsea. It happened to be my hotel for this stay, since I’d gotten a killer deal on the Internet.

abstract: The “Iron Lady” is an icon. But neither Michele Bachmann nor the film understand who Margaret Thatcher really was.
snippet: The “Iron Lady” is an icon. But neither Michele Bachmann nor the film understand who Margaret Thatcher really was.
lead_paragraph: It had to happen. For female politicians, invoking the name of Margaret Thatcher at a crucial time in your campaign is one of the canniest, most clichéd and most predictable of tactics.

abstract: Mr. Fisher, a Harvard law professor who was a co-author of the 1981 best seller “Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In,” led a role in drafting the Camp David accords.
snippet: Mr. Fisher, a Harvard law professor who was a co-author of the 1981 best seller “Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In,” led a role in drafting the Camp David accords.
lead_paragraph: Roger D. Fisher, a Harvard law professor who was a co-author of the 1981 best seller “Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In” and whose expertise in resolving conflicts led to a role in drafting the Camp David accords between Egypt and Israel and in ending apartheid in South Africa, died on Saturday in Hanover, N.H. He was 90.

abstract: During scores of trips to Haiti, Maggie Steber decided she had to find the country’s quiet moments. A new Web site showcases her 25-year search for beauty there.
snippet: During scores of trips to Haiti, Maggie Steber decided she had to find the country’s quiet moments. A new Web site showcases her 25-year search for beauty there.
lead_paragraph: To much of the outside world, the image of Haiti — when it pops up at all — is one of catastrophes, both natural and man-made. Violence, grinding poverty, flood, earthquakes all leave a lingering image of a benighted nation bereft of tender moments.
headline.main: Quietly Finding Haiti’s Audacious Beauty

abstract: Doctors have been fielding reports from patients that statins leave them feeling “fuzzy,” and unable to remember small and big things.
snippet: Doctors have been fielding reports from patients that statins leave them feeling “fuzzy,” and unable to remember small and big things.
lead_paragraph: After a heart attack and quadruple bypass surgery in 2010, Steve Colburn of Portland, Ore., began taking a cholesterol-lowering statin at the maximum dose. Soon, he began experiencing memory problems.
headline.main: A Heart Helper May Come at a Price for the Brain

abstract: Ms. James, most often referred to as a rhythm and blues singer, is in both the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and the Blues Hall of Fame.
snippet: Ms. James, most often referred to as a rhythm and blues singer, is in both the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and the Blues Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Etta James, whose powerful, versatile and emotionally direct voice could enliven the raunchiest blues as well as the subtlest love songs, most indelibly in her signature hit, “At Last,” died on Friday morning in Riverside, Calif. She was 73.

abstract: A new study finds that many home care agencies aren’t particularly scrupulous about vetting and training aides.
snippet: A new study finds that many home care agencies aren’t particularly scrupulous about vetting and training aides.
lead_paragraph: My mom, who had multiple sclerosis, depended on private-duty companions at home — first part time, then full time — for nearly 30 years.
headline.main: Who’s Watching Mom?

abstract: A generation of children in Big City India are growing up largely monolingual, although their parents speak many languages.
snippet: A generation of children in Big City India are growing up largely monolingual, although their parents speak many languages.
lead_paragraph: Sudhir Nagaraj and his wife, Bidisha, live in the mini-India that is Bangalore. She, a Bengali speaker from a family hailing from India’s east, heads marketing for a social networking start-up. He, fluent in the native Kannada tongue of Bangalore, runs a subsidiary of a multinational telecommunications company. Between them, they speak and understand half a dozen Indian languages. Quite ironic then that their daughter, Ahana, six-and-a-half, growing up in a country with a profusion of tongues, speaks only one language: impeccable English. And English is the common tongue that binds the Nagarajs as a family.

abstract: The Baylor-Tennessee game in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament showcased the sport Volunteers Coach Pat Summitt helped build.
snippet: The Baylor-Tennessee game in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament showcased the sport Volunteers Coach Pat Summitt helped build.
lead_paragraph: The end of the Baylor-Tennessee game in the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament was hard for everyone, with the 400-pound elephant in attendance at Des Moines’s Wells Fargo Arena representing the scary question of what the loss meant for Tennessee Coach Pat Summitt, whether it spelled the end of her legendary career and how big a toll her early-onset dementia would take on her in the coming years.

abstract: Kentucky’s pedestal has a downside as it prepares to meet Louisville in the Final Four, and the women’s final eight includes an emotional matchup between Tennessee and Baylor on Monday night.
snippet: Kentucky’s pedestal has a downside as it prepares to meet Louisville in the Final Four, and the women’s final eight includes an emotional matchup between Tennessee and Baylor on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky is the greatest team in college basketball. Maybe ever. John Calipari is a great coach, an incredibly smart hire by the Wildcats despite all those niggling N.C.A.A. investigations and vacated Final Fours. That his players hang around campus only slightly longer than the average grocery store visit, this is unimportant. See how fired up the faithful are? This is Kentucky. Anything less is unthinkable.

abstract: In Scott Lasser’s novel, a lawyer returns to his blighted hometown and decides that he can’t leave it.
snippet: In Scott Lasser’s novel, a lawyer returns to his blighted hometown and decides that he can’t leave it.
lead_paragraph: In the classic Motown song “Dancing in the Street,” Martha and the Vandellas sang, “Can’t forget the Motor City.” That’s easy enough to say when the topic is music: the MC5, the White Stripes, Bob Seger, Diana Ross, Smokey Robinson and countless other influential musicians have their roots there. But when it comes to literature, forgetting Detroit can be regrettably easy to do. The city may be one of our great, if crumbling, metropolises, yet contemporary fiction set there is sparse.  Dean Bakopoulos and Charles Baxter have written memorably about Detroit’s suburbs and nearby Ann Arbor. But fiction about present-day Detroit itself? Not so much lately; it’s almost as if novels themselves had had to flee the post-1960s urban blight.

headline.main: The 2012 Sidney Awards I
headline.print_headline: The 2012 Sidney Awards I

abstract: Hallucinations are often entirely normal and can be entertaining.
snippet: Hallucinations are often entirely normal and can be entertaining.
lead_paragraph: HALLUCINATIONS are very startling and frightening: you suddenly see, or hear or smell something — something that is not there. Your immediate, bewildered feeling is, what is going on? Where is this coming from? The hallucination is convincingly real, produced by the same neural pathways as actual perception, and yet no one else seems to see it. And then you are forced to the conclusion that something — something unprecedented — is happening in your own brain or mind. Are you going insane, getting dementia, having a stroke?

abstract: “Hope Springs” is another summer film aimed beyond the teenage and young-adult market. Movies like it and “The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel” are proving that older audiences exist.
snippet: “Hope Springs” is another summer film aimed beyond the teenage and young-adult market. Movies like it and “The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel” are proving that older audiences exist.
lead_paragraph: EVERY struggling young writer has been told “write what you know,” despite a digital library’s worth of contradictory evidence. Stephen Crane never went to war. Ray Bradbury never went to space. Dante, as far as we know, never went to hell. And Vanessa Taylor has never been married.

abstract: In “Food and Fadwa,” a co-production of Theater Noor and New York Theater Workshop, a Palestinian family copes with a menu, a wedding and another night of curfew on the West Bank.
snippet: In “Food and Fadwa,” a co-production of Theater Noor and New York Theater Workshop, a Palestinian family copes with a menu, a wedding and another night of curfew on the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Even the most meticulously prepared cook cannot be expected to cope with all kitchen disasters. A fully stocked spice rack, an ample larder and even a closet full of pickled staples will not necessarily suffice when a curfew keeps you housebound for more than a week with a family to feed.

abstract: For the elderly, it’s not always clear that the benefits of pet ownership outweigh the risks.

lead_paragraph: Think an elderly family member is better off with a pet? You may want to think again.
headline.main: Rethinking the Value of Pets

abstract: In Dan LeFranc’s play “The Big Meal” actors take turns portraying the members of a growing family across decades of life.
snippet: In Dan LeFranc’s play “The Big Meal” actors take turns portraying the members of a growing family across decades of life.
lead_paragraph: It would probably be wise to eat dinner before attending “The Big Meal,” a new play by Dan LeFranc that opened Wednesday night at Playwrights Horizons. The consumption of plates of everyday foods — chicken fingers and fries, spaghetti, mashed potatoes — becomes charged with ominous portent in this comic drama about love, marriage, child rearing and the general brisk rush of human life, in which you turn around and find that youth has vamoosed and taken with it a lot of your dearest held assumptions about the way things would turn out.

abstract: Attorney Craig Reaves on financial disclosures to siblings and repayment of loans.
snippet: Attorney Craig Reaves on financial disclosures to siblings and repayment of loans.
lead_paragraph: Craig Reaves, past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, practices elder law in Kansas City, Mo., and fields occasional questions from New Old Age readers. Submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your queries to general legal issues, as Mr. Reaves cannot respond with individualized legal advice. Questions have been edited and condensed.
headline.main: Ask the Elder Law Attorney: Disclosures and Loans

abstract: In Daniel Sullivan’s deflated production of “Glengarry Glen Ross,” subtext has been dragged to the surface and beached like a rusty submarine.
snippet: In Daniel Sullivan’s deflated production of “Glengarry Glen Ross,” subtext has been dragged to the surface and beached like a rusty submarine.
lead_paragraph: The fight has gone out of the once-robust boys from “Glengarry Glen Ross,” David Mamet’s 1984 Pulitzer Prize-winning drama of sharks in a small pond. Sure, they still curse and rant and beat up on the furniture in the production that formally opened at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on Saturday night, after an indecently extended preview period.

abstract: More Americans should take the initiative to spell out what treatments they do — and do not — want by writing living wills and appointing health care proxies.
snippet: More Americans should take the initiative to spell out what treatments they do — and do not — want by writing living wills and appointing health care proxies.
lead_paragraph: I WAS standing by my 89-year-old mother’s hospital bed when she asked a doctor, “Is there anything you can do here to give me back the life I had last year, when I wasn’t in pain every minute?” The young medical resident, stunned by the directness of the question, blurted out, “Honestly, ma’am, no.”

abstract: Long after her departure from public life, Margaret Thatcher, the former British prime minister who is the subject of a new film, still divides the British, even in her hometown.
snippet: Long after her departure from public life, Margaret Thatcher, the former British prime minister who is the subject of a new film, still divides the British, even in her hometown.
lead_paragraph: GRANTHAM, England — It is a poignant story, and the sparse audiences at the Reel Cinema, a few blocks from the handsome 18th-century facades of the town center, tell it as well as anything else.

abstract: Why you shouldn’t worry that your morning cup will harm your health or shorten your life.
snippet: Why you shouldn’t worry that your morning cup will harm your health or shorten your life.
lead_paragraph: A disclaimer: I do not own stock in Starbucks nor, to my knowledge, in any other company that sells coffee or its accouterments. I last wrote about America’s most popular beverage four years ago, and the latest and largest study to date supports that earlier assessment of coffee’s health effects.

abstract: Creating a specific plan can help ensure your wishes are being met and avoid divisive family conflicts and unwanted medical interventions.
snippet: Creating a specific plan can help ensure your wishes are being met and avoid divisive family conflicts and unwanted medical interventions.
lead_paragraph: Robert H. Laws, a retired judge in San Francisco, and his wife, Beatrice, knew it was important to have health care directives in place to help their doctors and their two sons make wise medical decisions should they ever be unable to speak for themselves. With forms from their lawyer, they completed living wills and assigned each other as health care agents.

abstract: In the “new old age,” social media is one of many ways of doing what nobody really knows how to do.
snippet: In the “new old age,” social media is one of many ways of doing what nobody really knows how to do.
lead_paragraph: Tales of Hurricane Sandy survival will likely emerge for years — particularly about the sick and elderly who were trapped in their homes or forced to evacuate under harrowing circumstances. Many of those stories have happy endings, like this one of social media and neighborliness I recently heard.

abstract: Neil Young has written a memoir, “Waging Heavy Peace,” whose subtitle sets the mood: “A Hippie Dream.”
snippet: Neil Young has written a memoir, “Waging Heavy Peace,” whose subtitle sets the mood: “A Hippie Dream.”
lead_paragraph: Not many authors explain their reasons for writing books as bluntly as Neil Young does in “Waging Heavy Peace.” First of all there’s the thing now known as the Keith Richards phenomenon: there turns out to be a large and lucrative market for memoirs from rock stars. In a two-page chapter called “Why This Book Exists” Mr. Young explains that his book will be a goose that lays a golden egg. He’s writing it because it will earn him enough money to stay off the stage for a while, which he badly needs to do for mental and physical reasons. “It all started when I broke my toe at the pool,” he explains.

abstract: An outbreak of fungal meningitis has focused attention on the reformulation of drugs, a prevalent practice that leaves many patients and even some doctors unclear about the origins of medications.
snippet: An outbreak of fungal meningitis has focused attention on the reformulation of drugs, a prevalent practice that leaves many patients and even some doctors unclear about the origins of medications.
lead_paragraph: When Julie Auslander’s son was sick and struggling to take his pills, she turned to a pharmacist, who made medicated patches for him to use instead. A few years later, when Ms. Auslander’s mother, who had dementia, needed anti-anxiety drugs but couldn’t swallow, Ms. Auslander turned again to a pharmacist, who prepared a special tablet that dissolved under the tongue.

abstract: While the jurors in the Jerry Sandusky child sexual abuse trial deliberated, Sandusky’s lawyer said he would be shocked if his client was acquitted on all 48 counts of abusing young boys that he faces.

lead_paragraph: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — With the jury in the Jerry Sandusky sex-abuse case deep into its second day of deliberation, Sandusky’s lawyer said Friday evening he would be shocked if his client was acquitted on all of the nearly 50 counts of abusing young boys he faced.

abstract: Msgr. William J. Lynn is the first supervisor of priests to be tried on charges of endangering children and conspiracy, in a landmark trial in Philadelphia.
snippet: Msgr. William J. Lynn is the first supervisor of priests to be tried on charges of endangering children and conspiracy, in a landmark trial in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: The landmark trial of a senior official of the Philadelphia Archdiocese who is accused of shielding priests who sexually abused children and reassigning them to unwary parishes began on Monday with prosecutors charging that the official “paid lip service to child protection and protected the church at all costs.”

abstract: Creativity isn’t a gift possessed by a lucky few, Jonah Lehrer says. It’s a process we can all learn to use more effectively.
snippet: Creativity isn’t a gift possessed by a lucky few, Jonah Lehrer says. It’s a process we can all learn to use more effectively.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wondered how Nike came by its famous slogan “Just Do It”? Neither have I, but it’s an interesting story. Dan Wieden was searching for a tag line to unify a series of ads his agency was making for Nike. Late one night he suddenly thought about the convicted murderer Gary Gil­more, whose last words before his execution were “Let’s do it.” Sitting at his desk Wieden turned that phrase over in his mind until it became “Just do it.” Accolades ensued.

abstract: The scientific and social forces that brought midlife America to its current state.
snippet: The scientific and social forces that brought midlife America to its current state.
lead_paragraph: An upbeat look at middle age? Patricia Cohen had her work cut out for her. Maybe there’s a capitalist culture somewhere that doesn’t make a blazing fetish of youthfulness and keep it stoked with huge amounts of commercial and medical hot air. If so, it’s not the one we live in. Yet nothing in the sometimes pathetic struggle of Americans over, say, 50 to claim a respectable place in the public consciousness puts Cohen in the grumpy mood she could so rightly claim after absorbing some 200 years of the history of middle age. Instead, she’s delivered a lively, well-researched chronicle of the social and scientific forces that brought midlife America to its current befuddled state — better off by most measures than any previous generation, but miserably out of fashion.

lead_paragraph: ARCOS DE LA FRONTERA, Spain — I still wonder how I ended up living in a former medieval bordello on the brink of a sandstone cliff on the southern frontier of Spain.

abstract: In films like “Robot & Frank” and “Prometheus,” technology of the not-so-distant future is on display.
snippet: In films like “Robot & Frank” and “Prometheus,” technology of the not-so-distant future is on display.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S a moment in the film “Robot & Frank” when Frank, an aging retiree with a helper robot installed in his life courtesy of his son, forgets that his caretaker is something other than human. The two are excitedly chatting when Frank gestures at his companion’s boxy outfit and asks, absent-mindedly, why he’s wearing a silly space helmet.

abstract: Older adults suffer disproportionately in the aftermath of traumas like Hurricane Sandy. Here are some ways to help them.
snippet: Older adults suffer disproportionately in the aftermath of traumas like Hurricane Sandy. Here are some ways to help them.
lead_paragraph: Let’s talk about the emotional aftermath of the storm that left tens of thousands of older people on the East Coast without power, bunkered down in their homes, chilled to the bone and out of touch with the outside world.

abstract: Karras, an All-Pro lineman for the Detroit Lions, gained attention for roles in the movies, like in “Blazing Saddles,” and on television, like in the sitcom “Webster.”
snippet: Karras, an All-Pro lineman for the Detroit Lions, gained attention for roles in the movies, like in “Blazing Saddles,” and on television, like in the sitcom “Webster.”
lead_paragraph: Alex Karras, a fierce and relentless All-Pro lineman for the Detroit Lions whose irrepressible character frequently placed him at odds with football’s authorities but led to a second career as an actor on television and in the movies, died Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 77.

abstract: In Michael Frayn’s novel, set in Greece, a charming sociopath assumes the identity of a famous lecturer. Mayhem ensues.
snippet: In Michael Frayn’s novel, set in Greece, a charming sociopath assumes the identity of a famous lecturer. Mayhem ensues.
lead_paragraph: Can the hoary trope of mistaken identity still play in the age of Google images? Especially if it’s a young, handsome womanizer with tousled blond hair being mistaken for the middle-aged, balding keynote speaker at the meticulously planned conference of a prestigious foundation?

abstract: The link between obesity and poverty is close and complicated, as leaders in one city learned when they tried to make high-calorie beverages more expensive.
snippet: The link between obesity and poverty is close and complicated, as leaders in one city learned when they tried to make high-calorie beverages more expensive.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Calif. — The California good life — the one of endless varieties of lettuce and tasting rooms nestled in vineyards — does not extend to Richmond’s Iron Triangle, a neighborhood named for the railroad tracks that delineate its borders and historically one of the neediest communities in the Bay Area.

abstract: In Sam Shepard’s murky new play, “Heartless,” a male academic with an unsettled life finds himself in a house full of unsettling women, most notably one played by Lois Smith.
snippet: In Sam Shepard’s murky new play, “Heartless,” a male academic with an unsettled life finds himself in a house full of unsettling women, most notably one played by Lois Smith.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the second act of “Heartless,” the murky new play by Sam Shepard, a luminous lunacy lights up the stage. It is generated by Lois Smith and Jenny Bacon, playing a mother and daughter who thus far haven’t had much to say to each other and wouldn’t even appear to have much in common, aside from that inconvenient matter of being related. But just listen to them now.

abstract: The partisan anger on MSNBC and Fox News this election season has never been as stark — and in some ways, as silly or small.

lead_paragraph: As the cable news channels count down the hours before the first polls close on Tuesday, an entire election cycle will have passed since President Obama last sat down with Fox News. The organization’s standing request to interview the president is now almost two years old.

abstract: In what psychologists call hindsight bias, many people will swear they predicted the results of events like next week’s election, even if they did not.

lead_paragraph: The economy, “super PAC” money, debate performances, the candidates’ personalities. Roll it all together, and it’s obvious who’s going to win.

abstract: Sometimes it’s best to tell white lies and omit certain truths with our elderly parents and grandparents, a doctor argues.
snippet: Sometimes it’s best to tell white lies and omit certain truths with our elderly parents and grandparents, a doctor argues.
lead_paragraph: Lou, my beloved grandfather, lived almost 101 years and obsessively worried every single day of his adult life — probably because his adult life began before it should have. As a child in Russia, he watched helplessly as his mother and sister were killed during a vicious pogrom in their village.

abstract: As more people in the United States remain childless, lawyers are emphasizing the importance of setting up health care proxies and powers of attorney.

lead_paragraph: SUSAN SOMMERS and her sister always kept a close eye on their mother, who was 94 and had dementia when she died this summer. Both sisters made sure they lived near their mother in Manhattan, and together they handled her bills, bought her food, took her to doctors’ visits and oversaw her caretakers.

abstract: Political rivalries and cultural tensions leave Yemen in an uneasy state of limbo ahead of talks to form a new constitution.

lead_paragraph: SANA, YEMEN — A year ago hundreds of thousands of people flocked to Sana’s Change Square and turned it into the symbolic heart of the revolution by calling from their tents for the resignation of President Ali Abdullah Saleh and euphorically debating the future of Yemen.

abstract: The knowledge I gained from reading every last word of Sports Illustrated.

abstract: A crushing inventory of claims for disability, pension and educational benefits has overwhelmed the Department of Veterans Affairs.
snippet: A crushing inventory of claims for disability, pension and educational benefits has overwhelmed the Department of Veterans Affairs.
lead_paragraph: For Dennis Selsky, a Vietnam-era veteran with multiple sclerosis, it was lost documents. It seemed that every time he sent records to the Department of Veterans Affairs, they disappeared into the ether.

abstract: The body — not exalted, but in its weaknesses — gets focus in many significant films of 2012, including “Amour,” “The Sessions” and “Rust and Bone.”
snippet: The body — not exalted, but in its weaknesses — gets focus in many significant films of 2012, including “Amour,” “The Sessions” and “Rust and Bone.”
lead_paragraph: SO many of the year’s best films have broken ground in their depiction of the realities of war, disability, aging, illness and death that I would call 2012 the year of the body. Not the body beautiful, which Hollywood has exalted for decades, but the body vulnerable. Even the male strippers in “Magic Mike,” Steven Soderbergh’s unsexy beefcake parade, are tarnished deities with feet of clay.

abstract: At a ceremony to honor the former Oakland running back Clem Daniels, players and John Madden said there had long been rewards for hard hitting in a violent sport.
snippet: At a ceremony to honor the former Oakland running back Clem Daniels, players and John Madden said there had long been rewards for hard hitting in a violent sport.

abstract: In light of increasing concussion research, nonprofessional hockey organizations are seriously considering rules changes that would effectively end brawling by players.
snippet: In light of increasing concussion research, nonprofessional hockey organizations are seriously considering rules changes that would effectively end brawling by players.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — Viewing fighting as a safety issue in light of increasing concussion research, and unwilling to wait for the National Hockey League to propose changes, USA Hockey and Hockey Canada are seriously considering rules that would effectively end fighting in nonprofessional leagues as soon as next season.

abstract: Right to Die-NL has created mobile teams to help patients die at home, and is now calling for legislation to make euthanasia available to anyone over age 70, sick or not.
snippet: Right to Die-NL has created mobile teams to help patients die at home, and is now calling for legislation to make euthanasia available to anyone over age 70, sick or not.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — It was 1989, and Dr. Petra de Jong, a Dutch pulmonologist, was asked for help by a terminally ill patient, a man in great pain with a large cancerous tumor in his trachea. He wanted to end his life.

abstract: Laurie Metcalf is back on Broadway with a familiar show, “The Other Place” (she did it off Broadway); a familiar director (Joe Mantello); and a familiar co-star (her daughter, Zoe Perry).
snippet: Laurie Metcalf is back on Broadway with a familiar show, “The Other Place” (she did it off Broadway); a familiar director (Joe Mantello); and a familiar co-star (her daughter, Zoe Perry).
lead_paragraph: FOR someone who pretty much worships Laurie Metcalf, Joe Mantello isn’t making her life easy in “The Other Place,” opening Jan. 10 on Broadway. “I used to leave the stage for a total of, like, 10 seconds,” Ms. Metcalf said of her experience in the show. “But we changed that.”

abstract: Julian Castro’s grandmother was an orphan. Michelle Obama’s father was a pump operator.
snippet: Julian Castro’s grandmother was an orphan. Michelle Obama’s father was a pump operator.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–The G.O.P. convention last week, an opportunity to introduce “the real” Mitt Romney to America, doubled as a genealogy of the Republican leadership. Bob McDonnell said his grandfather, a poor farm boy, left Ireland 100 years ago and came to Ellis Island; Ted Cruz said his dad was imprisoned and tortured in Cuba; and Chris Christie noted that his Irish father worked at the Breyers Ice Cream plant.
headline.main: Meet the Parents, Part II

abstract: A death in the family brings some lessons about how we can best approach our final days.
snippet: A death in the family brings some lessons about how we can best approach our final days.
lead_paragraph: ONE morning last month, Anthony Gilbey awakened from anesthesia in a hospital in the east of England. At his bedside were his daughter and an attending physician.

abstract: A long list of diseases that were once terminal can now be treated, but people must consider: Save a life or extend it? At what quality? At what price?
snippet: A long list of diseases that were once terminal can now be treated, but people must consider: Save a life or extend it? At what quality? At what price?
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Mike Otworth’s 10-year-old chow, Tina, was given a diagnosis of lymphoma. The prospects were grim. Lymphoma, a cancer of the lymph nodes that commonly develops in older dogs, can be put into remission through chemotherapy, but tumors almost inevitably reappear within a year, and death quickly follows.

abstract: A number of language immersion programs are offered in places like the Tuscan hills and Costa Rica, in classes specifically for older people or for a mix of age groups.
snippet: A number of language immersion programs are offered in places like the Tuscan hills and Costa Rica, in classes specifically for older people or for a mix of age groups.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS are not known for their facility with foreign languages, and learning gets more difficult as people age. But that has not stopped 60-, 70- and 80-somethings from heading to senior-friendly language immersion classes to tackle verb conjugations and the nuances of idioms — in places like the Tuscan hills and beach towns of Costa Rica.

abstract: How far would you go to modify yourself using the latest medical technology?
snippet: How far would you go to modify yourself using the latest medical technology?
lead_paragraph: IF a brain implant were safe and available and allowed you to operate your iPad or car using only thought, would you want one? What about an embedded device that gently bathed your brain in electrons and boosted memory and attention? Would you order one for your children?

abstract: Sotheby’s will auction treasures from two of Brooke Astor’s homes.
snippet: Sotheby’s will auction treasures from two of Brooke Astor’s homes.
lead_paragraph: IN her heyday as the bejeweled empress of New York philanthropy, Brooke Astor entertained presidents, first ladies and a potpourri of pooh-bahs and literati at her elegant 14-room duplex on Park Avenue. And when she died on Aug. 13, 2007, at Holly Hill, her estate in Westchester County, at 105, she left behind two households’ worth of cherished possessions, including Qing dynasty lacquer furniture, a jade-and-diamond Cartier clock and dozens of 19th-century dog portraits.

lead_paragraph: Getting through to troubled teenagers should not be difficult, says Julie Rodriguez, who aspires to be a counselor after surviving some tough decades of violence and drug abuse.

abstract: The same degenerative brain disease found in football players and boxers has been found in veterans exposed to roadside bombs, a finding with potentially profound implications.
snippet: The same degenerative brain disease found in football players and boxers has been found in veterans exposed to roadside bombs, a finding with potentially profound implications.
lead_paragraph: Scientists who have studied a degenerative brain disease in athletes have found the same condition in combat veterans exposed to roadside bombs in Iraq and Afghanistan, concluding that such explosions injure the brain in ways strikingly similar to tackles and punches.

abstract: Many older people need outside help long before they require round-the-clock care. Many assistance and housing alternatives have rapidly sprung up to meet this demand.
snippet: Many older people need outside help long before they require round-the-clock care. Many assistance and housing alternatives have rapidly sprung up to meet this demand.
lead_paragraph: My 92-year-old aunt, who is cognitively impaired and requires a walker or wheelchair to get around, still lives in her own apartment, where round-the-clock home health aides help her get to and from the bathroom, bathe, dress and undress, and go outside each day for some fresh air. The aides shop, prepare and serve meals, do light housekeeping and make sure she takes her medications on time.

abstract: Terry performed many jobs around our place but none more important, or better executed, than filling the aching void left by our father’s inaccessibility.
snippet: Terry performed many jobs around our place but none more important, or better executed, than filling the aching void left by our father’s inaccessibility.
lead_paragraph: A FEW years ago, while I was preparing to write a memoir about my father, I spent time looking through old photographs. One in particular, which I hadn’t seen in years, caught my attention. It’s not a typical family portrait. But by mid-20th-century America’s stingy definition, we weren’t a typical family.

abstract: Just because the wonder drugs of the ’90s have disappointed doesn’t mean the science should be completely discarded. But it does mean we need a more sophisticated theory of depression.
snippet: Just because the wonder drugs of the ’90s have disappointed doesn’t mean the science should be completely discarded. But it does mean we need a more sophisticated theory of depression.
lead_paragraph: Few medicines, in the history of pharmaceuticals, have been greeted with as much exultation as a green-and-white pill containing 20 milligrams of fluoxetine hydrochloride — the chemical we know as Prozac. In her 1994 book “Prozac Nation,” Elizabeth Wurtzel wrote of a nearly transcendental experience on the drug. Before she began treatment with antidepressants, she was living in “a computer program of total negativity . . . an absence of affect, absence of feeling, absence of response, absence of interest.” She floated from one “suicidal reverie” to the next. Yet, just a few weeks after starting Prozac, her life was transformed. “One morning I woke up and really did want to live. . . . It was as if the miasma of depression had lifted off me, in the same way that the fog in San Francisco rises as the day wears on. Was it the Prozac? No doubt.”

abstract: The program is the only safety net for millions of middle-class people whose needs for long-term care, at home or in a nursing home, outlast their resources.
snippet: The program is the only safety net for millions of middle-class people whose needs for long-term care, at home or in a nursing home, outlast their resources.
lead_paragraph: Medicaid has long conjured up images of inner-city clinics jammed with poor families. Its far less-visible role is as the only safety net for millions of middle-class people whose needs for long-term care, at home or in a nursing home, outlast their resources.

lead_paragraph: Speaking in front of a packed convention hall in Chicago, a top Alzheimer’s researcher, Sidney Gilman, presented the results of a drug trial that had the potential to change the fate of elderly patients everywhere.

abstract: Fifty years ago at Madison Square Garden, Emile Griffith delivered a pummeling to Benny Paret, who died after 10 days in a coma. Griffith was able to walk out, but not unscathed.
snippet: Fifty years ago at Madison Square Garden, Emile Griffith delivered a pummeling to Benny Paret, who died after 10 days in a coma. Griffith was able to walk out, but not unscathed.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years later. If you are Lucy Paret, though, the impoverished widow of Benny, a two-time welterweight champion of the world, you’re hardly calling this an anniversary. Fifty years ago, you decided to stay home in your Bronx apartment building the night your 25-year-old husband was pummeled to death — March 24, 1962 — by the challenger Emile Griffith, a former champion, on live television, an ABC “Friday Night Fights” special.

abstract: How to subtract 10 years from the age of your brain? Get a college degree.
snippet: How to subtract 10 years from the age of your brain? Get a college degree.
lead_paragraph: IN 1905, at age 55, Sir William Osler, the most influential physician of his era, decided to retire from the medical faculty of Johns Hopkins. In a farewell speech, Osler talked about the link between age and accomplishment: The “effective, moving, vitalizing work of the world is done between the ages of 25 and 40 — these 15 golden years of plenty.”

abstract: Unraveling the mystery of why the inhabitants of Ikaria, an island of 99 square miles that is home to almost 10,000 Greek nationals, live so long and so well.
snippet: Unraveling the mystery of why the inhabitants of Ikaria, an island of 99 square miles that is home to almost 10,000 Greek nationals, live so long and so well.
lead_paragraph: In 1943, a Greek war veteran named Stamatis Moraitis came to the United States for treatment of a combat-mangled arm. He’d survived a gunshot wound, escaped to Turkey and eventually talked his way onto the Queen Elizabeth, then serving as a troopship, to cross the Atlantic. Moraitis settled in Port Jefferson, N.Y., an enclave of countrymen from his native island, Ikaria. He quickly landed a job doing manual labor. Later, he moved to Boynton Beach, Fla. Along the way, Moraitis married a Greek-American woman, had three children and bought a three-bedroom house and a 1951 Chevrolet.

abstract: Hundreds of severely disabled citizens in Georgia are being reintegrated into society amid pressure from the Justice Department to end discrimination against the cognitively and physically impaired.
snippet: Hundreds of severely disabled citizens in Georgia are being reintegrated into society amid pressure from the Justice Department to end discrimination against the cognitively and physically impaired.
lead_paragraph: MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga. — On his last day in the state hospital, Wally Burns pulled on a new pair of plaid shorts and a neatly pressed polo shirt. He savored a final meal of eggs and grits, apple juice and milk, toast and a sweet doughnut stick.

abstract: Dr. Paul Butler created a stir when he suggested ending football at Dover High School in New Hampshire, citing evidence of the peril the sport poses to the brains of players.

lead_paragraph: DOVER, N.H. — The agenda for the Oct. 1 school board meeting did not call for anything particularly exciting. But during a segment called “Matters of Interest,” Paul Butler, a retired doctor and relative newcomer to the board, floated an idea: end the football program at Dover High School.

abstract: The Slave Theater in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, once a hub of civil rights activity, is mired in a bitter battle over ownership rights.
snippet: The Slave Theater in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, once a hub of civil rights activity, is mired in a bitter battle over ownership rights.
lead_paragraph: OVER a bustling stretch of Fulton Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the words on the faded marquee are as bracing as ever. “SLAVE #1,” it reads, in bold capital letters. Last week, amid the bright new chain stores that have popped up beside the Brooklyn neighborhood’s Caribbean-patty joints, the theater’s closed steel gate bore a warning from the Buildings Department: Anyone trying to enter would be subject to arrest. “The conditions in this premises,” the sign read, “are imminently perilous to life.” Above it was a plea for money: “Help Restore Historical Site. Get Involved!!!”

abstract: After “You Can Count on Me,” Lonergan made what may be the best film of the decade. So why did you never get to see it?
snippet: After “You Can Count on Me,” Lonergan made what may be the best film of the decade. So why did you never get to see it?
lead_paragraph: Think back on the last time you saw Kenneth Lonergan’s 2000 film, “You Can Count On Me.” Do you remember how good it was? The intellectual and emotional complexity of the script? Those remarkable performances by Mark Ruffalo and Laura Linney? That scene — to choose one among many — between Terry (Ruffalo) and his 8-year-old nephew, Rudy (Rory Culkin), in which the drunk Terry sits next to Rudy’s bed late at night, smoking a cigarette and telling Rudy why his dad is such a jerk and why the town he lives in sucks so much? (“Fortunately for you, though, your mom is like, the greatest. So you had some bad luck, and you had some good luck.”) It was a modest story of a brother and sister whose parents die when they’re kids and whose lives are blown in different directions and who, years later, come to some almost-peace about what they can and can’t be for each other. But there was such intense realness about it, the way people really talk, the way lives are actually lived, that was unlike anything else on screen, radical almost, in its attention to the genuine messiness of human lives.

abstract: One family with a genetic mutation is helping scientists find a cure.
snippet: One family with a genetic mutation is helping scientists find a cure.
lead_paragraph: It seemed as if it would be a perfectly ordinary occasion, that hot August day in 1959. Three generations of a large Oklahoma family gathered at a studio in nearby Perryton, Tex., to have a photo taken of the elders, 14 siblings ranging in age from 29 to 52. Afterward, everyone went to a nearby park for a picnic.
